Severe drought conditions continued during the month of January across far northern Illinois.  For the month of January, Rockford rainfall was 0.56 inches which was 1.04 inches below normal.  For the month of January, Waukegan rainfall was 0.65 inches, which was 0.76 inches below normal.

column37: Spotter and public reports of 1-3 inches of snow fell across portions of Whiteside County. Blowing and drifting snow continued to cause problems on roads after plowing, lasting into January 2nd. The highest snowfall report was 3 inches near Morrison.
column38: A strong winter storm impacted much of southeast Iowa, western Illinois, and northeast Missouri. Widespread snowfall ranging between 5 and 10 inches of snow was reported in the hardest hit areas, with 1 to 4 inches surrounding and gusty winds to follow. This event started and ended as a snow event, as cold air was in place prior. With the gusty winds, blowing and drifting snow was observed, reducing visibilities and making it difficult to measure the snowfall. Just as this storm was moving out, very cold temperatures moved in, with wind chills between -15 to -30 felt.

column37: Spotter and public reports of 4-8 inches of snow fell across portions of Henry County. Blowing and drifting snow continued to cause problems on roads after plowing, lasting into January 2nd. Verification was also considered using snow amounts and other combined hazards/impacts, with the highest snowfall report from a COOP Observer in Kewanee at 7.0 inches.

column37: A mix of snow, freezing rain and sleet fell in Adams County. An inch of sleet was reported in Quincy, IL with around an inch of snow on top of the sleet.
column38: An impactful winter storm moved through the Midwest on New Year's Day, which brought snow, sleet, and freezing rain to the region. Serious travel impacts occurred across portions of northeast Missouri and west central Illinois. Most of the area in the Winter Storm Warning only got between 1 and 4 inches of snow. However, there were several reports of 5 to 7 inches of snow over Knox County, a mix of up to 5 inches of snow and half an inch of sleet in Lewis County, and up to an inch of sleet in Quincy, IL (Adams County).

column37: Weather observers measured 3 to 5 inches of snow across Schuyler County.  The snowfall led to slippery road conditions and a few traffic accidents across the area.
column38: A strong frontal boundary extending from the Ohio River Valley into the southern Plains separated an unseasonably warm airmass characterized by temperatures in the 60s and 70s from Kentucky southward to the Gulf Coast from bitterly cold air with readings well below zero across the northern Plains into the Upper Great Lakes on January 1st.  Several waves of low pressure tracking along the boundary brought widespread precipitation to central Illinois.  With temperatures at or above freezing, most of the precipitation occurred in the form of rain east of the I-55 corridor...with a mix of rain, sleet, and snow between I-55 and the Illinois River.  Further northwest where a deeper cold airmass existed, all snow fell along and northwest of the Illinois River.  Snow totals were highest across portions of Knox and Stark counties, where amounts in excess of 6 inches were common.

column37: Numerous weather observers measured 3 to 6 inches of snow across Fulton County, with the highest totals occurring across the far northern part of the county.  5.0 inches was observed in Avon, Canton, and Farmington.  The snowfall led to slippery road conditions and a few traffic accidents across the area.

A winter storm moved across northern Illinois during the afternoon of January 1st through the early morning of January 2nd.  Snowfall totals were generally in the 3 to 5 inch range, with some higher totals across far northeast Illinois.  The highest totals included 6.5 inches in Hoffman Estates; 5.8 inches in Palatine; 5.5 inches two miles north of Waukegan; 5.4 inches in Evanston and Woodstock and 5.2 inches in Elgin.  Rockford Airport measured 4.8 inches and Chicago O'Hare Airport measured 4.1 inches.

A series of heavy rainfall events in late December and early January sent the Wabash River and large portions of the Ohio River above flood stage. The river flooding was minor. Low-lying farmland and fields along both rivers were flooded, as well as some river access roads and public recreational land.

column37: A band of heavy snow developed over southern Will County producing visibilities of one quarter mile or less.  Winds were gusting as high as 45 mph.
column38: A snow squall formed downwind of the Illinois River during the late morning of January 5th, producing a narrow band of heavy snow across portions of southern and eastern Will County.  Visibilities were one quarter mile or less with winds gusting as high as 45 mph.

column37: A band of heavy snow developed over eastern Will County producing visibilities of one quarter mile or less.  Winds were gusting as high as 45 mph.
column38: A snow squall formed downwind of the Illinois River during the late morning of January 5th, producing a narrow band of heavy snow across portions of southern and eastern Will County.  Visibilities were one quarter mile or less with winds gusting as high as 45 mph.

Around a deep 500 mb low centered just north of the Great Lakes, a shortwave pivoted east-southeast and intensified as it moved across the the Ohio Valley region. Temperatures fell well below freezing ahead of it, due to a cold front that swept through the previous day. Temperatures in the upper teens to lower 20's resulted in a dry, fluffy snow. These cold temperatures also allowed snow to quickly accumulate on roads. Two school busses skidded on the slick roads and became stuck in Johnson County. There were no injuries. Numerous minor wrecks were reported across the region. Snowfall totals were heaviest in the counties bordering the Ohio River, where about three inches fell. Amounts decreased to the north and west. Generally an inch or two fell across the rest of southern Illinois south of Interstate 64.

Around a deep 500 mb low centered just north of the Great Lakes, a shortwave pivoted east-southeast and intensified as it moved across the the Ohio Valley region. Temperatures fell well below freezing ahead of it, due to a cold front that swept through the previous day. Temperatures in the upper teens to lower 20's resulted in a dry, fluffy snow. These cold temperatures also allowed snow to quickly accumulate on roads. Two school busses skidded on the slick roads and became stuck in Johnson County. There were no injuries. Numerous minor wrecks were reported across the region. Snowfall totals were heaviest in the counties bordering the Ohio River, where about three inches fell. Amounts decreased to the north and west. Generally an inch or two fell across the rest of southern Illinois south of Interstate 64.

A series of heavy rainfall events in late December and early January sent the Wabash River and large portions of the Ohio River above flood stage. The river flooding was minor. Low-lying farmland and fields along both rivers were flooded, as well as some river access roads and public recreational land.

Freezing drizzle and freezing rain developed across northern Illinois during the early afternoon of January 8th and continued through the late evening.  Roads became slippery and numerous accidents and spin outs occurred.  Ice accumulation amounts at ASOS locations included 0.24 inches at DuPage Airport; 0.18 inches at both Chicago Midway and Aurora Airports; 0.15 inches at Chicago O'Hare and Chicago Executive Airports; 0.10 inch at Rockford Airport and 0.08 inches at Waukegan Airport.

column37: Spotter, COOP, COCORAHS, and public reports of 4-6 inches of snow fell across portions of McDonough County. Blowing and drifting snow continued to cause problems on roads after plowing, lasting into January 15th. The highest snowfall report from the event was 5.5 inches in Macomb.
column38: A winter storm brought snow to much of eastern Iowa, northwest Illinois, and northeast Missouri Friday afternoon - early Saturday morning.  This snow impacted the evening commute causing hazardous travel, especially between Des Moines and Iowa City on Interstate 80 and along I-380 between Iowa City and Cedar Rapids.  The highest snow totals between 8 and 12 inches were common roughly along a line from Des Moines to Keokuk.  Snow amounts between 4-7 inches were found across much of eastern Iowa towards west central Illinois.  Lesser amounts of 1-3 inches were reported in northern and north central Illinois.  ||Illinois, Iowa, and Missouri DOT reported slick and snow covered roads through much of the event.  Winds between 20-30 mph were also seen causing some blowing and drifting of snow.

column37: Spotter, COOP, and public reports of 5-8 inches of snow fell across portions of Hancock County. Blowing and drifting snow continued to cause problems on roads after plowing, lasting into January 15th. The highest snowfall report from the event was 7.3 inches in Bentley.

column37: Heavy snow fell across northern portions of Brown County. Up to 6 inches of snow fell in some locations.
column38: An upper level system moved into the region during the day on January 14th.  Widespread precipitation developed and spread across the region. Initially some locations had rain, but the rain quickly changed to all snow. It was a wet, heavy snow with snowfall rates up to an inch at times. A large portion of northeast Missouri and west central Illinois received over 6 inches of snow for this event.

column37: Heavy snow fell across Adams County. Up to 6.5 inches of snow fell in some locations.

A winter storm moved across northern Illinois from the late evening of January 22nd through the morning of January 23rd.  A band of lake effect snow developed over far eastern Cook and far eastern Will Counties as the snow ended late in the morning of January 23rd.  Snowfall totals generally ranged between 3 to 5 inches.  Rockford Airport measured 2.3 inches and Chicago O'Hare Airport measured 3.7 inches.

column37: A river ice spotter reported flooding of trails at the Kankakee State Park near the Warner Bridge due to an ice jam.  The water level dropped by one foot with ice marks left on nearby trees.  Sheet ice cover buckled due to the water level drop.
column38: An ice jam caused minor flooding along portions of the Kankakee River near Bonfield.

Lake effect snow developed over far northeast Illinois including Chicago during the early morning of January 28th and continued into the afternoon.  A band of heavy lake effect snow moved across parts of Cook County producing snowfall rates of 1 to 2 inches per hour.  Storm total snowfall amounts included 10.0 inches in Wilmette; 9.0 inches near Evanston and Skokie; 8.0 inches in Jefferson Park; 7.2 inches three miles southwest of Chicago Midway Airport; 7.1 inches in Harwood Heights; 6.0 inches in Lincoln Square and 3.3 inches at Chicago O'Hare Airport.

column37: Numerous spotter reports showed 8 to 12 inches of snow fell across central and southern portions of McDonough county.  Emergency Managers report that significant drifting snow continued to close roads, after plowing, during the afternoon of February 2nd. The highest totals of 12-14 inches were received just south of Macomb.
column38: While not a very strong storm, this system had open access to moist Gulf air, which ended up dropping large snowfall totals through parts of the Midwest. This storm started out as rain early on 2/1, which quickly switched to snow after 6:00 PM and remained snow through the duration of the event. The snow added up to very significant totals over much of central Illinois, which extended into west central Illinois and northeast Illinois. In that band, snow amounts of 8 to 12 inches were common, with a few reports as high as 14 inches.  While snow diminished during the day February 2nd, cold north winds brought significant drifting snow issues to counties that saw the heaviest snow totals.

column37: Numerous spotter reports showed 8 to 12 inches of snow fell across central and southern portions of Hancock county. The highest totals of 13.5 inches were received at Augusta, Illinois from the COOP observer.

Chicago O'Hare Airport measured 5.6 inches and the National Weather Service office in Romeoville measured 10.0 inches.

column37: Between 8 to 10 inches of snow fell across Pike County.
column38: A cold front, that was draped northeast-southwest across western Iowa and eastern Nebraska/Kansas, moved south and entered the county warning area during the morning of February 1st.  Broad moist isentropic ascent and overrunning precipitation developed across the entire county warning area gradually through the late morning into the afternoon of February 1st, with the baroclinic zone initially serving as the focus for rain. This first round of precipitation stayed nearly all rain, but snow did begin to mix with rain in northern Missouri and west-central Illinois during the afternoon hours of February 1st as colder air advanced south behind the front.  The cold air became more established in the northwest half of the CWA with wet snow and a snowfall rate approaching 1/hr across parts of northeast Missouri and west central Illinois north of the I-70 corridor during the early morning hours of February 2nd.  The first round brought a wide swath of at least 6-10 inches of snow (with some sleet mixed in) across central/east-central Missouri and west-central Illinois. A second round of heavy snow fell along and south of the I-70 corridor with snowfall rates in excess of 0.5 per hour and occasionally brief periods of 1.5 per hour on Thursday, February 3rd.  An additional 6-8 of snow fell in this area during the morning/afternoon hours of February 3rd with lighter snowfall over northeast Missouri and west central Illinois.

column37: Weather observers measured 6 to 12 inches of snow across Fulton County...including 10.0 inches in Canton, 9.0 inches in Astoria, and 6.0 inches in Avon.  The heavy snow accumulations and considerable blowing and drifting snow led to road closures and numerous traffic accidents.
column38: A slow-moving cold front dropped southward through central Illinois on February 1st, bringing an end to a period of unseasonably warm temperatures in the 40s and lower 50s. Several waves of low pressure tracked along the boundary, producing widespread precipitation across the region. The precipitation started as rain, then transitioned to wet snow along and north of a Quincy to Lincoln line by the late evening of February 1st. Snow developed southward to just north of I-70 by daybreak on February 2nd, then to locations south of I-70 by the late afternoon and evening of the 2nd. Once the snow tapered off and came to an end by the evening of February 3rd, widespread totals of 6 to 10 inches were observed everywhere north of I-70...with a heavier swath of snow exceeding 12 inches from a Minonk to Beardstown line northeastward to the Indiana border.  Along and south of I-70, mixed phase precipitation occurred.  Snow totals of 6 to 8 inches were common along I-70, but tapered off to 3 to 5 inches further south.  Ice accumulations were focused along I-70, where amounts of two tenths to as much as three tenths of an inch were reported. In addition to the snow, strong northerly winds gusting as high as 30 to 40mph caused considerable blowing and drifting snow, which led to road closures and numerous traffic accidents across central Illinois.

column38: A slow-moving cold front dropped southward through central Illinois on February 1st, bringing an end to a period of unseasonably warm temperatures in the 40s and lower 50s. A winter storm moved across northern Illinois on February 2nd producing heavy snow along and south of a line from Mendota to Aurora to Evanston, where snowfall amounts of 8 to 14 inches occurred.  Snow amounts quickly diminished northwest of this line.  Snowfall rates of 1 to 2 inches per hour were observed in the heaviest snow bands.||The highest storm total snowfall totals included 14.3 inches in Mokena; 13.8 inches two miles northwest of Chicago Heights; 13.0 inches in Paxton, Gibson City and Kankakee; 12.6 inches in Minooka; 12.5 inches in Lansing; 12.0 inches in Pontiac; 11.6 inches in Streator and New Lenox; 11.5 inches in Danforth, Frankfort, Lockport and near Emington; 11.2 inches near Burr Ridge; 11.0 inches in Homewood, Oak Lawn, Oak Forrest, Morris, Bradley, Herscher, Fairbury, Crest Hill, Joliet, Elwood and Braidwood.  Chicago O'Hare Airport measured 5.6 inches and the National Weather Service office in Romeoville measured 10.0 inches.

column37: There were two rounds of precipitation with this system. The first round was rain changing to a mix of sleet and snow, then another round of heavy snow. Around half an inch of sleet was reported in parts of Clinton County during the morning hours of February 2nd. With the second round of precipitation, storm total snowfall ranged from 5 to 7 inches.
column38: A cold front, that was draped northeast-southwest across western Iowa and eastern Nebraska/Kansas, moved south and entered the county warning area during the morning of February 1st.  Broad moist isentropic ascent and overrunning precipitation developed across the entire county warning area gradually through the late morning into the afternoon of February 1st, with the baroclinic zone initially serving as the focus for rain. This first round of precipitation stayed nearly all rain, but snow did begin to mix with rain in northern Missouri and west-central Illinois during the afternoon hours of February 1st as colder air advanced south behind the front.  The cold air became more established in the northwest half of the CWA with wet snow and a snowfall rate approaching 1/hr across parts of northeast Missouri and west central Illinois north of the I-70 corridor during the early morning hours of February 2nd.  The first round brought a wide swath of at least 6-10 inches of snow (with some sleet mixed in) across central/east-central Missouri and west-central Illinois. A second round of heavy snow fell along and south of the I-70 corridor with snowfall rates in excess of 0.5 per hour and occasionally brief periods of 1.5 per hour on Thursday, February 3rd.  An additional 6-8 of snow fell in this area during the morning/afternoon hours of February 3rd with lighter snowfall over northeast Missouri and west central Illinois.

A second round of heavy snow fell along and south of the I-70 corridor with snowfall rates in excess of 0.5 per hour and occasionally brief periods of 1.5 per hour on Thursday, February 3rd.  An additional 6-8 of snow fell in this area during the morning/afternoon hours of February 3rd with lighter snowfall over northeast Missouri and west central Illinois.

column37: There were two rounds of precipitation with this system. The first round was rain changing to a mix of sleet and snow, then another round of heavy snow. Up to a quarter of an inch of sleet as well as a couple inches of snow was reported in parts of Jersey County during the morning hours of February 2nd. With the second round of precipitation, storm total snowfall ranged from 6 to 9 inches.
column38: A cold front, that was draped northeast-southwest across western Iowa and eastern Nebraska/Kansas, moved south and entered the county warning area during the morning of February 1st.  Broad moist isentropic ascent and overrunning precipitation developed across the entire county warning area gradually through the late morning into the afternoon of February 1st, with the baroclinic zone initially serving as the focus for rain. This first round of precipitation stayed nearly all rain, but snow did begin to mix with rain in northern Missouri and west-central Illinois during the afternoon hours of February 1st as colder air advanced south behind the front. column37: Weather observers measured 6 to 10 inches of snow across Moultrie County...including 9.9 inches in Lovington and 5.8 inches 3 miles south of Sullivan.  The heavy snow accumulations and considerable blowing and drifting snow led to road closures and numerous traffic accidents.
column38: A slow-moving cold front dropped southward through central Illinois on February 1st, bringing an end to a period of unseasonably warm temperatures in the 40s and lower 50s. Several waves of low pressure tracked along the boundary, producing widespread precipitation across the region. The precipitation started as rain, then transitioned to wet snow along and north of a Quincy to Lincoln line by the late evening of February 1st. Snow developed southward to just north of I-70 by daybreak on February 2nd, then to locations south of I-70 by the late afternoon and evening of the 2nd. Once the snow tapered off and came to an end by the evening of February 3rd, widespread totals of 6 to 10 inches were observed everywhere north of I-70...with a heavier swath of snow exceeding 12 inches from a Minonk to Beardstown line northeastward to the Indiana border.  Along and south of I-70, mixed phase precipitation occurred.  Snow totals of 6 to 8 inches were common along I-70, but tapered off to 3 to 5 inches further south.  Ice accumulations were focused along I-70, where amounts of two tenths to as much as three tenths of an inch were reported. In addition to the snow, strong northerly winds gusting as high as 30 to 40mph caused considerable blowing and drifting snow, which led to road closures and numerous traffic accidents across central Illinois.

A winter storm moved across northern Illinois on February 2nd producing heavy snow along and south of a line from Mendota to Aurora to Evanston, where snowfall amounts of 8 to 14 inches occurred.  Snow amounts quickly diminished northwest of this line.  Snowfall rates of 1 to 2 inches per hour were observed in the heaviest snow bands.||The highest storm total snowfall totals included 14.3 inches in Mokena; 13.8 inches two miles northwest of Chicago Heights; 13.0 inches in Paxton, Gibson City and Kankakee; 12.6 inches in Minooka; 12.5 inches in Lansing; 12.0 inches in Pontiac; 11.6 inches in Streator and New Lenox; 11.5 inches in Danforth, Frankfort, Lockport and near Emington; 11.2 inches near Burr Ridge; 11.0 inches in Homewood, Oak Lawn, Oak Forrest, Morris, Bradley, Herscher, Fairbury, Crest Hill, Joliet, Elwood and Braidwood.  Chicago O'Hare Airport measured 5.6 inches and the National Weather Service office in Romeoville measured 10.0 inches.

A major winter storm dumped significant amounts of snow and sleet across southern Illinois. Some freezing rain also occurred, mainly along the Ohio River from Metropolis to Shawneetown. The highest snow amounts were along and west of Interstate 57 from Mount Vernon to Marion, where several inches of snow fell on top of a layer of sleet. Isolated amounts of 7 to 8 inches were reported in the Carbondale and DuQuoin areas (Jackson and Perry Counties). Most other places northwest of a line from Fairfield (Wayne County) to Harrisburg (Saline County) to Anna (Union County) reported 4 to 5 inches of mainly snow on a layer of sleet. Snowfall rates were as high as 3/4 inch per hour, which reduced visibility below a mile. In the Ohio River counties, where precipitation was all sleet and freezing rain, one-tenth inch to one-quarter inch of ice was under about three-quarters inch of sleet. Widespread major travel impacts were reported across the region. Roads were covered with an icy mix that resulted in traffic accidents. A strong cold front moved slowly southeast across the lower Ohio Valley and southeast Missouri on February 2nd. Precipitation changed from rain to a mix of wintry precipitation on the 2nd. Along and west of Interstate 57 from Mount Vernon to Marion,  the cold air became deep enough for plenty of snow.

Snowfall rates were as high as 3/4 inch per hour, which reduced visibility below a mile. Widespread major travel impacts were reported across the region. Roads were covered with an icy mix that resulted in traffic accidents. A strong cold front moved slowly southeast across the lower Ohio Valley and southeast Missouri on February 2nd. Precipitation changed from rain to a mix of wintry precipitation on the 2nd. Along and west of Interstate 57 from Mount Vernon to Marion,  the cold air became deep enough for plenty of snow.

column37: Weather observers measured 3 to 5 inches of snow across Clay County...including 5.0 inches in Flora and 4.8 inches 6 miles south-southeast of Clay City.  The snowfall created hazardous driving conditions, which led to several traffic accidents across the area.
column38: A slow-moving cold front dropped southward through central Illinois on February 1st, bringing an end to a period of unseasonably warm temperatures in the 40s and lower 50s. Several waves of low pressure tracked along the boundary, producing widespread precipitation across the region. The precipitation started as rain, then transitioned to wet snow along and north of a Quincy to Lincoln line by the late evening of February 1st. Snow developed southward to just north of I-70 by daybreak on February 2nd, then to locations south of I-70 by the late afternoon and evening of the 2nd. Once the snow tapered off and came to an end by the evening of February 3rd, widespread totals of 6 to 10 inches were observed everywhere north of I-70...with a heavier swath of snow exceeding 12 inches from a Minonk to Beardstown line northeastward to the Indiana border.  Along and south of I-70, mixed phase precipitation occurred.  Snow totals of 6 to 8 inches were common along I-70, but tapered off to 3 to 5 inches further south.  Ice accumulations were focused along I-70, where amounts of two tenths to as much as three tenths of an inch were reported. In addition to the snow, strong northerly winds gusting as high as 30 to 40mph caused considerable blowing and drifting snow, which led to road closures and numerous traffic accidents across central Illinois.

Light freezing rain and freezing drizzle developed across portions of northeast Illinois during the early morning of February 7th.  The precipitation transitioned to flurries and very light snow after sunrise.  Waukegan Airport measured 0.03 inches of ice accumulation and Chicago Executive Airport measured 0.02 inches of ice accumulation.

column37: Minor flooding occurred on the Ohio River. Some low-lying fields and woodlands were underwater.
column38: A nearly stationary front sagged slowly southeast across the region from the 1st to the 4th. Heavy rainfall on the 2nd was followed by snow and sleet on the 3rd and 4th. Rainfall totals and liquid water equivalents during this time totaled between 2 and 3 inches. Some minor river flooding ensued.

South winds gusted as high as 40 to 55 mph across parts of southern Illinois, mainly west of Interstate 57. The peak measured gust in southern Illinois was 54 mph at the Carbondale airport. The strong winds occurred between a surface cold front over the central Plains and a strong high off the Carolina coast.

column37: Heavy snow fell across the county with storm total snowfall between 6 and 8 inches.
column38: A strong storm system developed with a cold front moving slowly south across the region. A round of sleet and freezing rain developed north of the boundary across portions of central/northeast Missouri and west central Illinois. Then the mixed precipitation changed over to all snow before coming to an end. Some locations reported between half an inch and 1.5 inches of sleet, as well as up to 11 inches of snow.

column37: Weather observers measured 6 to 10 inches of snow across Schuyler County...including 8.4 inches in Rushville and 7.5 inches 3 miles east-northeast of Rushville.  Falling and blowing snow led to hazardous driving conditions and numerous traffic accidents across the area.
column38: Low pressure tracking from the Ozarks during the pre-dawn hours of February 17th to southern Ohio by the evening of the 17th brought heavy snow to parts of central Illinois.  Snowfall amounts of greater than 6 inches were focused along and north of the I-72 corridor...with a swath of 8 to 10-inch totals along a Quincy to Bloomington-Normal line.  As the low deepened over the Ohio River Valley, northerly wind gusts increased to 35 to 45mph, creating considerable blowing and drifting snow.  As a result, travel quickly became hazardous and several area roadways were closed.  Stretches of both I-55 and I-74 were closed near Bloomington.  In addition, numerous accidents created a 100 vehicle pileup on southbound I-39 between Normal and Minonk, which closed the interstate for about 24 hours.

A winter storm moved across northern Illinois on February 17th producing a period of heavy snow during the afternoon and evening.  Winds were gusting to 30 mph producing widespread blowing and drifting snow.  Numerous traffic accidents were reported.||Snowfall amounts were generally in the 3 to 5 inch range across much of the central and southern Chicago Metro area with amounts quickly decreasing across the northern suburbs.  The highest snowfall totals were generally along and south of Interstate 80.  Some of the highest storm total snowfall amounts included 8.0 inches in Gibson City; 7.0 inches in Strawn; 6.5 inches near Kankakee; 6.0 inches in Streator and near Fairbury; 5.5 inches six miles east of Ashkum; 5.0 inches in Chatsworth and three miles west of Marseilles.  Chicago O'Hare Airport measured 2.9 inches.

column37: A vehicle nearly stalled out on a flooded section of road a few miles south of Herrin. Near Energy, several locations were under water on secondary roads.
column38: Several rounds of heavy rain and thunderstorms moved across the region on the 17th. Two to four inches were common, which resulted in isolated flash flooding and more widespread flooding of rivers. The heavy rain occurred ahead of a cold front as it entered southeast Missouri and southern Illinois from the northwest. Weak waves of low pressure moved northeast along the front. A strong 850 mb jet up to 60 to 70 knots was accompanied by a strong surge of warm moist air through the Mississippi River Valley.

As the low deepened over the Ohio River Valley, northerly wind gusts increased to 35 to 45mph, creating considerable blowing and drifting snow.  As a result, travel quickly became hazardous and several area roadways were closed.  Stretches of both I-55 and I-74 were closed near Bloomington.  In addition, numerous accidents created a 100 vehicle pileup on southbound I-39 between Normal and Minonk, which closed the interstate for about 24 hours.

A winter storm moved across northern Illinois on February 17th producing a period of heavy snow during the afternoon and evening.  Winds were gusting to 30 mph producing widespread blowing and drifting snow.  Numerous traffic accidents were reported.||Snowfall amounts were generally in the 3 to 5 inch range across much of the central and southern Chicago Metro area with amounts quickly decreasing across the northern suburbs.  The highest snowfall totals were generally along and south of Interstate 80.  Some of the highest storm total snowfall amounts included 8.0 inches in Gibson City; 7.0 inches in Strawn; 6.5 inches near Kankakee; 6.0 inches in Streator and near Fairbury; 5.5 inches six miles east of Ashkum; 5.0 inches in Chatsworth and three miles west of Marseilles.  Chicago O'Hare Airport measured 2.9 inches.

column37: Widespread 5 to 8 inch  snow amounts were reported over McDonough County by spotters. The highest snow totals, around 8 inches, were reported near Macomb, Illinois.
column38: A winter storm brought a mix of precipitation to all of eastern Iowa, northwest Illinois and far northeast Missouri beginning on the evening of Feb 16, and ending in the late afternoon of Feb 17. Areas observed rain at first, but saw a transition over to snow by the morning of Feb 17. Snow amounts of 3 to 6 inches were measured the evening of Feb 17, and were most prevalent in far northeast Missouri and west central Illinois. A few amounts of 7 to 8 inches were observed over far southern McDonough and Hancock counties in Illinois, where snow bands persisted longer. Snow totals decreased to the north and west, where dry air aloft prevented much in the way of northward progression of snow.

column37: Widespread 5 to 6 inch  snow amounts were reported over Hancock County by spotters.

column37: Flooding was reported along the Vermilion River near East 1251st Road, northeast of Leonore, due to an ice jam.
column38: The combination of warmer temperatures and snow melt produced an ice jam on the Vermilion River northeast of Leonore during the late morning and early afternoon of February 18th.

A strong cold front moved across northern Illinois during the evening of February 18th producing snow squalls as a band of heavy snow developed along this cold front.  Visibilities were one quarter mile or less with several reports of visibility of only a few hundred feet.  Winds gusted between 45 and 50 mph.  Many locations received a quick 1 to 2 inches of snow across northwest Illinois.  The snow began to weaken as it moved across northeast and central Illinois during the late evening.  Blowing snow continued into the overnight hours.

column37: Conditions reported showed a rapid onset of snow and blowing snow with the snow squall. This was reported by local media, as well as various observing sites at airports showing lowered visibility.
column38: The evening of February 18th, a powerful cold front quickly moved through eastern Iowa and northwest Illinois. A narrow band of intense snow squalls accompanied this front, bringing a near instantaneous onset of brief winter storm conditions. Roads went from dry to snow covered in a matter of minutes, temperatures fell from around 35 to 28 in minutes, and visibility fell from over 6 miles to under 1/4 mile as the snow squall arrived. Snow accumulation generally was a 1/2 inch to 1 inch, falling in around 1 hour. Once the snow squall ended, dry and windy conditions continued the rest of the night.

column37: Moderate flooding occurred on the Little Wabash River. At the Carmi river gage, the river crested at 32.94 feet on the evening of the 27th. Flood stage is 27 feet. There was considerable flooding of low-lying farmland and fields. Some rural back country roads were under water. The river remained above flood stage into March.

column37: Moderate flooding occurred on the Wabash River. At Mount Carmel, the river crested at 26.4 feet on the 28th. Flood stage is 19 feet. Some farm operations were affected, such as moving equipment to higher ground. Extensive lowland flooding occurred, affecting numerous local river roads.  Installation of flood gate A at Mount Carmel was necessary.  County Road 1280 E and South Division Street were flooded. The flooding continued into March.

Warm air spread across the area along with heavy rain and thunderstorms during the early morning of February 22nd.  Some of the thunderstorms produced small hail.  A cold front then moved into northern Illinois bringing freezing rain to far northern Illinois.  The heavy rain caused localized flooding.||Ice accumulation amounts from the freezing rain included 0.15 inches in Woodstock; 0.10 inches at McCullom Lake, Towers Lake, near Lakewood and three miles northeast of Woodstock; 0.09 inches at Waukegan Airport; 0.05 inches at Rockford Airport and 0.01 inches at Chicago Executive Airport.

Parts of southern Illinois received a winter storm, consisting of two periods of sleet and freezing rain. The winter storm area was generally along and west of a line from Mount Vernon to Marion to Anna-Jonesboro, including Carbondale. Within this area, a period of sleet and freezing rain occurred during the evening of the 23rd, followed by a more significant round of wintry precipitation on the 24th. Ice accumulations ranged from one-quarter to one-third inch, along with about one-half inch of sleet. The precipitation on the 24th was accompanied by frequent thunder and lightning at times. Driving conditions were  hazardous at times. Isolated power outages occurred due to tree damage from freezing rain accretion. Hundreds of customers were without power at the peak of the outages. A tree was uprooted by ice and fell onto a power line several miles southeast of Carbondale. Over the rest of southern Illinois, mainly east of Interstate 57, there was only one round of impactful winter precipitation. This round occurred on the evening of the 23rd, causing travel hazards during the evening commute. The accumulations of sleet and freezing rain in these areas, including Carmi  and Harrisburg, were generally below one-quarter inch. Temperatures on the 24th were just warm enough for little or no impact from the precipitation in this area. ||The wintry precipitation was caused by a moist southwest flow aloft, associated with a 500 mb trough over the western Plains. At the same time, surface high pressure advancing from the northern Plains produced a cold northerly surface wind. The cold low levels enabled the precipitation to stay freezing rain and sleet from the Marion-Carbondale area north and west, but temperatures inched above freezing elsewhere. The second round of precipitation on the 24th was enhanced by a low pressure center that tracked northeast across Tennessee.

Ice accumulations ranged from one-quarter to one-third inch, along with about one-half inch of sleet. The precipitation on the 24th was accompanied by frequent thunder and lightning at times. Driving conditions were  hazardous at times. Isolated power outages occurred due to tree damage from freezing rain accretion. Hundreds of customers were without power at the peak of the outages. A tree was uprooted by ice and fell onto a power line several miles southeast of Carbondale. Over the rest of southern Illinois, mainly east of Interstate 57, there was only one round of impactful winter precipitation. This round occurred on the evening of the 23rd, causing travel hazards during the evening commute. The accumulations of sleet and freezing rain in these areas, including Carmi  and Harrisburg, were generally below one-quarter inch. Temperatures on the 24th were just warm enough for little or no impact from the precipitation in this area. ||The wintry precipitation was caused by a moist southwest flow aloft, associated with a 500 mb trough over the western Plains. At the same time, surface high pressure advancing from the northern Plains produced a cold northerly surface wind. The cold low levels enabled the precipitation to stay freezing rain and sleet from the Marion-Carbondale area north and west, but temperatures inched above freezing elsewhere. The second round of precipitation on the 24th was enhanced by a low pressure center that tracked northeast across Tennessee.

column37: Up to seven tenths of an inch of sleet was reported in Madison County.
column38: A strong storm system moved through the region on February 23rd through 24th. The area most affected by the sleet was along and south of a Jefferson City, Missouri to Carlinville, Illinois line. A number of locations reported between half an inch and two inches of sleet with this storm.

Light snow moved across most of northern Illinois during the afternoon of February 24th and transitioned to a mix of light snow and light freezing drizzle and freezing rain for areas south of Interstate 80, in east central Illinois.  These areas received a light glaze of ice accumulation.  Another period of light snow occurred from the evening of February 24th through the early morning of February 25th and mainly for areas along and north of Interstate 80.  Storm total snowfall amounts were generally 1 to 3 inches, except in far northeast Illinois where a localized area of 3 to 5 inches of snow occurred, generally along and north of Interstate 90.

River flooding continued from February into mid March. During March, the flooding was minor on the Wabash, Little Wabash, and Big Muddy Rivers. Low-lying fields and woodlands near these rivers were inundated, primarily dormant cropland. However, moderate flooding was observed on large portions of the Ohio River. The flooding was caused by several rounds of heavy rain and thunderstorms on the 17th of February.

column37: Moderate flooding occurred on the Ohio River. The river crested at 47.11 feet at the Cairo river gage on the 3rd, which is 7.11 feet above flood stage. Low-lying fields and woodlands in the flood plain were underwater. Fort Defiance State Park near Cairo was partially flooded.

Severe drought conditions ended across far northern Illinois at the end of March.  For the month of March, Rockford rainfall was 2.92 inches, which was 0.52 inches above normal.  For the month of March, Waukegan rainfall was 2.84 inches, which was 0.62 inches above normal.

column37: Moderate flooding occurred on the Ohio River. The river crested at 44.58 feet at the Paducah, KY river gage on the 2nd, which is about 5.5 feet above flood stage. column37: The ASOS at the Moline Quad Cities Airport measured a peak gust of 56 knots during the thunderstorm.
column38: Severe thunderstorms tracked across northwest Illinois  during the late afternoon and evening of Saturday March 5, 2022. Thunderstorms initially developed in southwest Iowa, and moved across central Iowa during the afternoon hours, before crossing the Mississippi River into northwest Illinois during evening hours. Storms produced damaging winds and a tornado in northwest Illinois. Winds around 60-75 MPH were reported from trained spotters and first responders, with confirmed reports of damage in some locations. There was an EF-1 tornado northeast of Erie, Illinois.

column38: A cold front pushing across Iowa and Missouri interacted with a warm and moist environment to trigger a line of strong to severe thunderstorms during the late afternoon of March 5th.  The storms advanced eastward into central Illinois during the evening, producing wind gusts of 50-60mph and sporadic damage.  An EF-0 tornado touched down northeast of Kilbourne in Mason County causing damage to farm irrigation systems, power poles, and a few trees.

column37: A brief tornado touched down on the evening of March 5th, 2022 just south of Farmersville, IL. The tornado first touched down near East 2nd Road, where it did damage to a one story residence. At this location, the tornado ripped the roof off the garage of a home and the awning off the front porch. The tornado continued northeast, doing some minor damage to a farm building just west of Interstate 55. As it crossed Interstate 55, it blew over a semi truck on the highway. The tornado continued east of Interstate 55, doing substantial damage to some large farm buildings along Morrisonville Avenue and East 4th Road. From there, the tornado began to weaken as it struck a newly constructed hog farm along East 5th Road, before quickly lifting near Macoupin Creek. Overall, the tornado was rated EF-1 with a path length of 3.89 miles and a max path width of 40 yards. No deaths or injuries were reported.

column38: Scattered severe thunderstorms moved across northern Illinois during the late evening of March 5th producing high winds and scattered wind damage.

A cold front pushing across Iowa and Missouri interacted with a warm and moist environment to trigger a line of strong to severe thunderstorms during the late afternoon of March 5th.  The storms advanced eastward into central Illinois during the evening, producing wind gusts of 50-60mph and sporadic damage.  An EF-0 tornado touched down northeast of Kilbourne in Mason County causing damage to farm irrigation systems, power poles, and a few trees.

column37: Dime to nickel size hail fell in the Harrisburg to Carrier Mills corridor.
column38: Small clusters of intense storms moved northeastward along a surface warm front during the early evening. These storms were associated with a strengthening low-level jet and some cooling aloft. Despite very weak instability, isolated damaging winds occurred in extreme southeast Illinois.

column37: A weather service storm survey found scattered thunderstorm wind damage in an area three to five miles north of Golconda along Highway 146. A manufactured home had most of its roofing material removed. A small portion of roofing was blown off a metal barn. A few small tree limbs were down. Peak winds were estimated between 70 and 75 mph.
column38: Small clusters of intense storms moved northeastward along a surface warm front during the early evening. These storms were associated with a strengthening low-level jet and some cooling aloft. Despite very weak instability, isolated damaging winds occurred in extreme southeast Illinois.

column37: Multiple machine sheds and outbuildings were destroyed near Duncanville just east of Highway 1.
column38: An area of low pressure tracking along a nearly stationary frontal boundary brought showers and thunderstorms to southeast Illinois during the evening of March 6th.  One of the thunderstorm cells became severe across Crawford County, causing significant wind damage near Duncanville.

Snow developed across northern and central Illinois during the afternoon of March 10th and continued through the early morning of March 11th.  Snowfall amounts generally ranged between 3 and 5 inches south of Interstate 80 with amounts quickly decreasing to an inch or less across far northern Illinois.

A band of locally heavy snow shifted southeast across most of southern Illinois during the afternoon hours. Most places south of Interstate 64 received one to two inches of snow, however a few isolated amounts of three to four inches were reported. Visibility was reduced to one-quarter mile or less where the heaviest snow banding occurred. Since pavement temperatures were above freezing, most of the accumulation was on grassy areas. However, some slushy accumulations on roadways caused locally hazardous travel in the heaviest snow band. Storm total snowfall reports included 4 inches on the west side of Carbondale, 3 inches at Thompsonville (Franklin County), 2 inches at Murphysboro, two inches at Crossville (White County), 1.5 inches at Tamms (Alexander County), one inch at Marion, and one inch at Cobden (Union County). The snow was caused by a surface low pressure system which organized over the southern Plains and then tracked along a stationary front that was stretched along the Ohio River.

The Wabash River rose above flood stage once again at New Harmony. The flooding was minor, consisting of low-lying fields. The flooding was the result of repeated rounds of showers and thunderstorms from mid February to mid March.

column37: The ASOS at the Moline-Quad Cities Airport measured a peak wind gust of 60 MPH with a rain shower.
column38: A cold front swept across the area on Friday March 25th, with widespread wind speeds of 20 to 30 MPH with gusts up to 45 MPH. Rain showers developed behind the cold front with reported wind gusts between  50 to 60 MPH. There was a reported wind gusts at the Moline Quad Cities Airport of 60 MPH. Winds began to diminish during the evening hours.

High winds developed during the afternoon of March 25th along with convective showers that produced localized wind damage.  A wind gust to 60 mph was measured at Rockford Airport and a tree was blown down near Fairmont in Will County.

Strong and gusty south to southwest winds developed ahead of a strong cold front that trailed southward from a low pressure center passing north of the region. A very strong low-level jet strengthened to around 80 knots, which set the stage for both strong gradient winds and thunderstorm winds. The peak measured non-thunderstorm wind gust in southern Illinois was 53 mph at the Carbondale airport. There was a power outage from a blown transformer in Valier, just west of Benton. A tree fell onto a house in Murphysboro. Minimal damage was reported to the house.

A very strong low-level jet strengthened to around 80 knots, which set the stage for both strong gradient winds and thunderstorm winds. The peak measured non-thunderstorm wind gust in southern Illinois was 53 mph at the Carbondale airport. There was a power outage from a blown transformer in Valier, just west of Benton. A tree fell onto a house in Murphysboro. Minimal damage was reported to the house.

column37: Street flooding was reported in several locations in Williamson County, mainly along and northwest of a line from Herrin to Carterville. The water was six to eight inches deep.
column38: A broken squall line of showers and thunderstorms produced scattered pockets of strong winds and a few tornadoes. The strongly forced squall line was accompanied by several transient meso-vortices within an environment of very strong low level wind shear. Very limited instability reduced the longevity of these meso-vortices. Dew points  in the upper 50's ahead of the line proved sufficient for a few tornadoes. A very strong low-level jet in excess of 80 knots supported the wind damage and tornado events along the line. Lightning was absent at times from the line. The line formed ahead of a strong cold front that trailed southward from a low pressure center passing north of the region. A very strong 500 mb shortwave pivoted east-northeast from the southern Plains, further enhancing the convection despite weak instability.

column37: Trees were uprooted and snapped. Three outbuildings were partially damaged. A few houses sustained shingle damage. There was roof and siding damage to homes in Akin. Maximum winds were estimated near 80 mph based on a storm damage survey.

column37: A brief touchdown occurred along Walnut Grove Road. There was a public eyewitness of the tornado. Shingle damage occurred to a few houses. Some larger branches on a few trees were snapped. There was minor damage to a couple of outbuildings. Peak winds were estimated near 75 mph.

column37: This tornado formed in rural farm country several miles southwest of Carmi, then tracked northeast across residential areas in the southeast and east central parts of the city of Carmi. At least a dozen houses received shingle damage, mostly in Carmi. A few large sheds were extensively damaged, one of which was completely destroyed. Some of the debris from a shed was blown into an assisted living center in Carmi. Dozens of trees were uprooted or snapped, some of which blocked roads. One small johnboat was blown into a pond. Power poles and lines were down along the path. Peak winds based on a storm damage survey were estimated near 100 mph.

column37: A man tried to drive across a flooded road near the intersection of 1600 East and County highway 26 southwest of Shelbyville on the morning of March 31st.  His car was pushed off the road by the current, and he was swept away after exiting the vehicle.  24-hour rainfall in the area ranged from 2.5 to 3 inches.
column38: A strong cold front brought widespread showers and thunderstorms to central Illinois from the afternoon of March 30th through the pre-dawn hours of March 31st.  24-hour rainfall totals ranged from 2 to 3 inches, which caused localized flash flooding of a few rural roads.  A man tried to drive across a flooded roadway southwest of Shelbyville in Shelby County at around 7:30am CDT on March 31st.  His vehicle stalled, and he was swept away by the current when he exited.  His body was recovered in a drainage creek on April 2nd.

column37: Minor flooding ended on the Wabash River very early in the month. Some low-lying cropland was underwater.
column38: Following a very wet March, a somewhat drier pattern in April allowed flooding to recede on the Wabash River.

A late winter storm brought accumulating snow to portions of northwest Illinois on April 2nd.  Snowfall amounts were generally in the 2 to 5 inch range along and north of a Polo to Belvidere to Woodstock line.  Rockford Airport measured 1.7 inches of snow.

A brief period of strong gusty winds occurred on the back side of a rain shield associated with a mesoscale convective system. The area of strong winds was confined to a few counties in extreme southern Illinois along the Ohio River, from Cairo to Metropolis. The estimated peak wind gusts were near 40 mph based on observations from neighboring counties in Missouri and Kentucky.

High winds developed across northern Illinois during the afternoon of April 14th producing localized wind damage.  Measured wind gusts include 63 mph near West Brooklyn; 63 mph at the Waukegan Airport; 60 mph near Herbert and near Darien; 59 mph at the Chicago O'Hare and Chicago Midway Airports and 58 mph at DuPage Airport.  A large tree limb was blown down onto a car along Hutchinson Street in the Uptown neighborhood of Chicago.  An 8 inch diameter tree was uprooted in Herrick Lake Forest Preserve near Warrenville Road and a section of a fence was also blown down nearby. A tree fell blocking Portwine Road, north of Deerfield Road in Riverwoods.  A semi truck was blown over along Interstate 55 near Pontiac.

Freezing temperatures were observed over parts of southern Illinois, mainly from Mount Vernon to Carbondale westward. The lowest temperature reported was 30 degrees at the Mount Vernon airport. Lows were near freezing over most the area. The freeze was late enough in the growing season to damage any unprotected strawberry crops, as well as a wide variety of other fruit crops and flowering ornamental shrubs and trees. A surface high pressure ridge was centered from Iowa across eastern Missouri, providing light winds  and clear skies favorable for cold early morning temperatures.

Between a strong low pressure system over the Dakotas and high pressure off the Carolina coast, strong south winds gusted to between 40 and 50 mph. The strongest winds were over the Mississippi River counties of southern Illinois, extending into Marion. Peak wind gusts measured during the afternoon hours were 49 mph at the Southern Illinois Airport near Carbondale and 41 mph at the Williamson County Airport.

column37: Four trees were blown down, including one that fell onto a house.  Part of the roof of a tin shed was ripped off, the guttering of another shed was damaged, and a sign was broken.
column38: A cold front interacting with a seasonably warm and humid airmass triggered a broken line of strong to severe thunderstorms across central Illinois during the afternoon of April 24th.  One of the cells spawned a brief EF-1 tornado northeast of Sharpsburg in Christian County.  Meanwhile other storms produced wind gusts of 50 to 60mph and isolated damage across portions of Sangamon and Christian counties.

column37: A well-constructed shed was blown over.

column37: A tornado touched down 3 miles east-northeast of Sharpsburg at 5:49 PM CDT.  The tornado demolished a 60 by 120-foot shed along East 1900 North Road just west of North 1300 East Road.  Damage from the shed was thrown about a mile to the east-northeast.  The tornado quickly dissipated 4 miles east-northeast of Sharpsburg at 5:50 PM CDT.

column37: Water started to come over Highway 45 and other nearby roads that typically experience water problems near Jeffersonville.
column38: Locally heavy rain occurred with thunderstorms ahead of a cold front.

A thunderstorm that was originally a supercell over southeast Missouri produced a couple reports of severe weather after crossing into southwest Illinois. The storm weakened with loss of daytime heating in the evening. The storm formed earlier in the day immediately ahead of a cold front across southeast Missouri, where lower 60's dewpoints were in place.
Scattered severe thunderstorms moved across northern Illinois on April 30th producing three tornadoes, large hail, localized wind damage and minor flooding.

column37: Sterling Illinois Airport observed wind gust from a thunderstorm.
column38: Strong thunderstorms developed the afternoon of April 30th. A severe wind gust was measured by the Sterling Illinois Airport AWOS.

column37: A large area of straight line wind damage occurred near 135th Street, west of Route 59.  Several tree limbs 6 to 10 inches in diameter were blown down near the intersection of 135th Street and Meadow Lane.  A large section of siding was ripped off the south side of a house on Meadow Lane, just south of 135th Street.  Two large trees were blown down on 135th Street, about a third of a mile west of Meadow Lane.  A sod farm irrigation pivot was blown into fences and yards, damaging the fences along the west side of Meadow Lane.  A private weather station measured a gust to 65 mph at this location.  Between Meadow Lane and Van Dyke Road, along 135th Street, multiple tree limbs were blown down; an 8 inch diameter pine tree was snapped halfway up the trunk; fence panels were damaged and trampolines were flipped.  The damage was consistent with wind speeds estimated to 75 mph.
column38: Scattered severe thunderstorms moved across northern Illinois on April 30th producing three tornadoes, large hail, localized wind damage and minor flooding.

column37: A photo showed flood waters several inches deep on Lambert Road near McCreey Avenue.

column37: Minor flooding was reported near Roosevelt Road and Nicoll Way.

column37: A tornado with peak winds to 75 mph touched down just west of the Hilton Hotel and Willow Crest Golf Club, where an outbuilding had its roof removed.  The tornado moved northeast, crossing Route 83 near Route 34 and then moved across Central Park where a light post was blown down.  The tornado lifted just east of Jorie Boulevard.  Tree limbs were snapped and a few trees were uprooted along the path of this tornado.

column37: After reviewing drone footage and radar data, it was determined that a narrow swath of straight line winds between 70 and 80 mph occurred near the intersection of 9th Street and Broadway Street southeast of downtown Rockford.  These winds caused the loss of a roof to a building south of Broadway which subsequently resulted in the collapse of the west and south facing walls.  Roofing material from this building was blown in a north and northeast direction.  Several utility poles and trees were snapped along 9th Street, with additional minor roof damage noted in the vicinity.  The damage orientation was consistent with a divergent area of southerly straight line winds.
column38: Scattered severe thunderstorms moved across northern Illinois on April 30th producing three tornadoes, large hail, localized wind damage and minor flooding.
Scattered severe thunderstorms moved across northern Illinois on April 30th producing three tornadoes, large hail, localized wind damage and minor flooding.

A cold front triggered a line of strong to severe thunderstorms across central Illinois during the late afternoon and evening of April 30th.  One of the storms spawned a brief rain-wrapped tornado in rural McLean County southwest of Colfax.  No damage was reported.  Other storms along the line produced hail as large as half dollars and a few damaging wind gusts.  The storms primarily impacted locations from the I-55 corridor eastward to I-57 before weakening as they tracked further east later in the evening.

column37: Thunderstorm winds blew down several large tree limbs around town.

A cold front triggered a line of strong to severe thunderstorms across central Illinois during the late afternoon and evening of April 30th.  One of the storms spawned a brief rain-wrapped tornado in rural McLean County southwest of Colfax.  No damage was reported.  Other storms along the line produced hail as large as half dollars and a few damaging wind gusts.  The storms primarily impacted locations from the I-55 corridor eastward to I-57 before weakening as they tracked further east later in the evening.

column37: A tornado with peak winds of 80 mph touched down just west of Candlewick Lake, near the intersection of Candlewick Drive and Briar Cliff Street.  Several softwood trees were uprooted and snapped at the start of the path and laid in a convergent pattern.  The tornado continued northeast across Candlewick Lake, where several floating docks were thrown across the lake.  The tornado lifted as it reached the eastern side of the lake.

column38: A thunderstorm that was originally a supercell over southeast Missouri produced a couple reports of severe weather after crossing into southwest Illinois. column37: A storm chaser reported a nearly stationary landspout on the ground, kicking up dust. There was no observable damage to assign an EF-scale rating.
column38: A line of showers and thunderstorms developed during the late afternoon of Friday, May 13, 2022 generally along and east of the Mississippi River in northwest Illinois. Some thunderstorms did become severe along that line, and produced all modes of severe weather including hail up to one inch, wind gusts to 60 MPH and three landspout tornadoes. One occurred near Good Hope IL, with the other two just south of Monmouth IL. Some reports of flooding were also received, especially near Roseville IL.

A slow-moving cold front interacting with a seasonably warm and moist airmass triggered a broken line of strong to severe thunderstorms across west-central Illinois during the late afternoon and early evening of May 13th.  One of the strongest cells within the line dropped golf ball-sized hail near Brooklyn in Schuyler County.  Other storms produced excessive rainfall rates that led to minor flash flooding across portions of Schuyler and Fulton Counties.

column37: The intersection of 12th and Main Streets was impassible due to flood waters.  Standing water was reported on other roads.  Many ditches were full or overflowing.
column38: Scattered thunderstorms moved across northwest Illinois during the evening of May 13th.

A cold front interacting with a seasonably warm and moist airmass triggered scattered strong thunderstorms across east-central and southeast Illinois during the afternoon and early evening of May 14th. Hail as large as nickels was reported near the town of Casey in Clark County.
Storms developed along a weak frontal boundary across the southern half of the forecast area. Some of the storms became severe with several reports of large hail and damaging winds.

column37: A trained spotter reported one-inch hail over downtown Carbondale. There was a public report of half-dollar size hail in the city. The total length of the hailstorm was two minutes.
column38: A few small clusters of strong to severe thunderstorms occurred during the evening. The storms were ahead of a cold front that extended from northwest Illinois through central Missouri.

column37: Pea-size hail was also observed by the trained spotter.
column38: A few small clusters of strong to severe thunderstorms occurred during the evening. The storms were ahead of a cold front that extended from northwest Illinois through central Missouri.

A cold front interacting with a seasonably warm and moist airmass triggered scattered strong thunderstorms across east-central and southeast Illinois during the afternoon and early evening of May 15th.  Hail as large as nickels was reported in Newman in Douglas County.

A cold front interacting with a seasonably warm and moist airmass triggered scattered strong thunderstorms across east-central and southeast Illinois during the afternoon and early evening of May 15th.  Hail as large as nickels was reported in Newman in Douglas County.

column37: A brief tornado was captured on several videos. It touched down about half a mile south of the intersection of Boone Street and Hoots Chapel Road, to the east of Hoots Chapel Road in an empty field. Duration was likely less than 1 minute, no damage or injuries. The tornado was rated EFU with an estimated path length of 0.11 miles and an estimated path width of 30 yards.
column38: As a cold front moved through the region, it triggered showers and storms. Some of the storms became severe with reports of damaging winds, large hail and a brief tornado.

A cold front interacting with a seasonably warm and moist airmass triggered scattered strong thunderstorms across east-central and southeast Illinois during the afternoon and early evening of May 15th.  Hail as large as nickels was reported in Newman in Douglas County.

A complex of storms over southwestern Missouri during the early morning hours of May 19th, moved east northeast along the I-70 corridor. Some of the storms became severe with several reports of damaging winds.

An area of low pressure tracking along a nearly stationary frontal boundary extending from the Ozarks into the Ohio River Valley brought several clusters of strong to severe thunderstorms to southeast Illinois during the afternoon and evening of May 19th.  One storm dropped quarter-sized hail west of Hardinville in Crawford County, while other cells produced wind gusts of around 60mph and minor wind damage across portions of Effingham and Lawrence Counties.

column37: Thunderstorm winds blew down several trees onto Illinois Route 155 in Ruma. Numerous tree limbs were blown down in Baldwin. In the Sparta and Eden areas, numerous trees, tree limbs and power lines were blown down. Several buildings in Sparta sustained minor damage from fallen trees and tree limbs.
column38: During the early afternoon of Thursday, May 19, 2022, a complex of thunderstorms expanded and intensified over sections of south-central Missouri. Thunderstorms quickly became strong to severe as the complex tracked east-northeast, impacting east-central Missouri, southeast Missouri, west-central Illinois and southwest Illinois. Numerous thunderstorms embedded within the broad complex exhibited signs of rotation, resulting in nine confirmed tornadoes. Of the nine tornadoes, six tornadoes occurred in Missouri and three occurred in Illinois. In Missouri, five of the six tornadoes were rated EF-0 and one tornado was rated EF-1. In Illinois, two tornadoes were rated EF-0, while the third was rated EF-1. In addition to the nine tornadoes, several locations were impacted by straight-line wind damage. The greatest impact from straight-line winds extended west to east through sections of southeast Missouri into southwest Illinois. The most extensive straight-line wind damage was in a swath from Desloge, MO through Chester, IL. Between the tornadoes and straight-line winds, much of the damage was similar in nature, taking out several trees, damaging outbuildings, machine sheds, and a few grain silos. Some residential homes also suffered damage, largely due to fallen trees, large limbs and/or flying debris. No fatalities nor injuries were reported.

column37: Widespread wind damage across Chester. Numerous trees, tree limbs, power poles and power lines were blown down around town. Also, a couple of houses sustained damage from fallen trees.  Several businesses were damaged as well.

Between the tornadoes and straight-line winds, much of the damage was similar in nature, taking out several trees, damaging outbuildings, machine sheds, and a few grain silos. Some residential homes also suffered damage, largely due to fallen trees, large limbs and/or flying debris. No fatalities nor injuries were reported.

column37: A weak tornado touched down over a residence just east of Summerfield Street/St. Jacob Road, 1 mile north of Summerfield, IL. Trees suffered damage on the property before the tornado continued north-northeast through a small, open field. The tornado impacted a row of trees on the north edge of the field, entered another field and lifted approximately one minute after initially developing. Overall, the tornado was rated EF0 with a path length of 0.23 miles and a max path width of 50 yards. No deaths or injuries were reported.

column37: A weak tornado touched down briefly 2.8 miles east-southeast of Okawville, Illinois, traveled 1.6 miles northeast and lifted 3.9 miles east-northeast of Okawville, Illinois. A few sheds and outbuildings suffered damage along the path of the tornado, including one shed that was completely destroyed. Maximum wind speed of the tornado was estimated at 85 mph at the site of the destroyed shed. Crop damage was also observed. Overall, the tornado was rated EF0 with a path length of 1.65 miles and a max path width of 50 yards. No deaths or injuries were reported.

column37: A tornado with estimated maximum wind speeds of 110 mph impacted northern Clinton and southern Bond counties in Illinois. The tornado touched down around 5:57 PM 3.6 miles north of Breese (Clinton County), just west of Jamestown Road, about half a mile south of intersection with Tin Shanty Road. Three farms in this area sustained damage to a number of buildings, as well as one residence. The tornado continued to travel to the north northeast with additional damage to several more residences and outbuildings before crossing into southern Bond County, at the intersection of Keysport Road and Schrage Road. The tornado was rated EF1 in Clinton County with a path length of 5.75 miles and a max path width of 250 yards. No deaths or injuries were reported.

column37: The tornado crossed into southern Bond County at the intersection of Keysport Road and Schrage Road. It continued to travel to the north northeast. It caused roof damage to an outbuilding as well as snapping off a couple of large trees at a farm on Drake School Road, just west of intersection with Millersburg Road. It eventually crossed Interstate 70 just southwest of Exit 45 on the southeast side of Greenville. It lifted and dissipated along Illinois Route 127 just north of intersection with Bowman Industrial Drive. The tornado was rated EF1 in Bond County with a path length of 10.9 miles and a max path width of 250 yards. No deaths or injuries were reported. Overall, the tornado was rated EF1 with a path length of 16.65 miles and a max path width of 250 yards.

column37: Several trees, tree branches, and power lines were blown down.  Power outages were reported in Effingham, Lake Sara, and Funkhouser.
column38: An area of low pressure tracking along a nearly stationary frontal boundary extending from the Ozarks into the Ohio River Valley brought several clusters of strong to severe thunderstorms to southeast Illinois during the afternoon and evening of May 19th.  One storm dropped quarter-sized hail west of Hardinville in Crawford County, while other cells produced wind gusts of around 60mph and minor wind damage across portions of Effingham and Lawrence Counties.

column37: A weather observer reported an estimated wind gust of 60mph.

column37: Widespread wind damage occurred in Crossville, including very large tree branches that were snapped. Many trees were blown down or uprooted, along with structural damage to several buildings and houses. Numerous power lines were blown down.
column38: An organized complex of thunderstorms accompanied a pronounced mesoscale convective vortex (MCV) as it tracked across Missouri and Illinois. column37: The tornado touched down near Keensburg and moved northeast, passing across the southeast portion of Mount Carmel and across the Wabash River into Indiana. A few homes lost large portions of roofing, mainly shingles. Outbuildings and small sheds were destroyed. Numerous power lines were down. Many trees were snapped or uprooted. Many trees landed on homes and structures, causing some structural damage. Dozens of power poles were snapped off. A large machine shed lost small sections of metal roof and wall  panels. Several pivot irrigation systems were flipped. Peak winds were estimated near 115 mph in Wabash County. The tornado crossed the Wabash River into Gibson County, Indiana.

column37: Public report relayed by broadcast media. A gustnado removed a side panel from a metal building near Alpha. Time estimated by radar.
column38: Lingering thunderstorms from the night before continued into the morning, with the northern extent of the system reaching into Henry County Illinois shortly after sunrise. This storm generated relatively strong outflow, which led to a brief gustnado in Alpha. This gustnado caused minor structural damage.

column37: As a line of storms moved through town, numerous large tree limbs were blown down and an 8 inch diameter tree was snapped off.
column38: A line of storms moved through southern Illinois. Some of the storms produced damaging winds.

column37: Several large trees were snapped or uprooted, and large limbs were blown down. A couple of the limbs landed on roads and houses. Shingles were blown off a few houses.  One older house sustained significant roof damage.
column38: A cluster of thunderstorms over parts of southern Illinois intensified as it moved into an increasingly unstable air mass as temperatures warmed to near 80. Gradually strengthening southwesterly winds in the low and mid levels of the atmosphere aided in the formation of an organized line. The line of storms posed a gradually increasing threat for damaging winds as it encountered a more unstable air mass. The storms formed in the vicinity of a cold front as it sagged southeast toward western Indiana, southern Illinois, and south central Missouri.

column37: A wind gust to 61 mph was clocked at the Carmi Municipal Airport.

column37: A brief tornado caused damage at a farmstead just southeast of the Albertus Airport. The tornado caused significant damage to an outbuilding, destroyed a grain bin, and snapped tree trunks. The tornado was rated EF1 with maximum winds around 100 mph. The tornado was on the ground for nearly 2 miles. Start and end times were estimated by radar. There were no injuries reported. Assistance from Stephenson County Emergency Management in completing the survey is greatly appreciated.
column38: A brief spin-up tornado occurred Wednesday afternoon just south of Freeport near the airport.  No injuries were reported.

column37: A rotating wall cloud with a brief funnel cloud was observed from east Wheaton.

One cell dropped hail as large as quarters near Marshall in Clark County, while other storms produced winds of 50-60mph and minor wind damage across parts of Clark and Christian Counties.

column37: Based on multiple spotter reports, a brief tornado touched down in a field just south of Coffman Road two miles south of Baileyville.  Spotters reported rotating dust underneath a funnel cloud.  The tornado was on the ground for approximately 30 seconds.  No damage was reported.
column38: A brief tornado occurred in northwest Ogle County during the afternoon of May 26th.

column37: A tornado touched down northwest of Industry, IL on the evening of May 31, 2022. The tornado lofted a grain bin, damaged a farm outbuilding and snapped a power pole along Highway 67. The tornado was on the ground for just over 1.5 miles. Start and end times were estimated by radar. There were no injuries/fatalities reported. Assistance from McDonough County Emergency Management in completing the survey is greatly appreciated.
column38: Thunderstorms developed across all of eastern Iowa, northwest Illinois and far northeast Missouri on the afternoon and evening of May 31, 2022. Initially, storms were not severe as they worked through an environment that was lacking strong mid-level instability. This changed as storms reached west central Illinois, where some atmospheric recovery was able to take place during the late afternoon hours from cloud cover during the day. A strong storm developed in northwest Illinois, which spawned a brief tornado that led to some damage. In addition, torrential rain fell across the area and led to flash flooding across southern portions of Hancock and McDonough counties. Several roads were washed out and rivers were out of their banks. The La Moine River at Colmar rose to moderate flood stage as well.

column37: Water from a nearby creek flowed over a bridge, and was around a foot deep in places.

column38: An area of thunderstorms moved over the same areas repeatedly, and resulted in very heavy rain and flash flooding in west central Illinois in the early morning hours of June 1st, 2022.

Several loosely organized clusters of thunderstorms produced localized strong wind gusts and isolated hail. The lack of greater vertical wind shear limited organization of the storms. A cold front moved south-southeast from the Plains and Great Lakes, preceded by multiple thunderstorm outflow boundaries. The storms reached their peak intensity during the late afternoon and early evening, when the diurnal peak of instability was reached.

column38: A slow-moving cold front interacted with a warm and moist environment to trigger clusters of thunderstorms across north-central Illinois during the late afternoon and evening of June 6th.  Some of the storms produced rainfall of 1 to 3 inches in a short period of time, leading to localized flash flooding.  The flooding was primarily focused along and north of an Abingdon to Lacon line.

column37: Pine tree and farm windmill knocked over. Time estimated with radar data.
column38: Severe storms impacted Illinois the evening of June 6th.

column37: Water was flowing across the roadway at the intersection of Illinois 17 and Illinois 40 just west of Camp Grove.
column38: A slow-moving cold front interacted with a warm and moist environment to trigger clusters of thunderstorms across north-central Illinois during the late afternoon and evening of June 6th.  Some of the storms produced rainfall of 1 to 3 inches in a short period of time, leading to localized flash flooding.  The flooding was primarily focused along and north of an Abingdon to Lacon line.
Scattered thunderstorms moved across northern Illinois during the afternoon and evening of June 6th.

Areas of dense fog reduced visibility to one-quarter mile or less across most of southern Illinois. The dense fog was mainly in the counties along and west of Interstate 57, but also included the Ohio River counties from Metropolis to Shawneetown. The dense fog formed in a moist air mass ahead of a cold front over Missouri and central Illinois.

column37: There was also some crop and tree damage relayed with no detail.
column38: Strong to severe storms moved through west central Illinois early in the morning hours of June 12, 2022. Both damaging winds and large hail occurred, with a microburst damaging farm roofs.

Areas of low pressure tracking along a stationary frontal boundary draped across central Illinois triggered two large thunderstorm clusters during the morning of June 12th.  One cluster impacted Champaign and Vermilion Counties, causing minor wind damage and dropping hail as large as ping pong balls.  The second cluster formed further west and brought damaging wind gusts, large hail, and flash flooding to portions of Schuyler and Morgan Counties.

A disturbance on the periphery of an upper-level ridge moved through Illinois, generating showers and storms. Some of the storms became severe producing damaging winds and large hail.
