column37: Widespread wind damage between Womac and Honey Bend. Multiple small to medium sized trees snapped off. Also, several trees were uprooted near the intersection of Kirkland and Sumpter Roads. One large tree was blown down blocking Illinois Route 108 near intersection with Standard City Road. On Barnett Road, several power poles were blown down between Leefers Road and South Atwater Road. An unoccupied camper was blown over at a house on Illinois Route 108 near intersection with South Atwater Road. A machine shed was destroyed on Dickey Road with the debris blown approximately a quarter of a mile to the east southeast.  No deaths or injuries were reported.
column38: A disturbance on the periphery of an upper-level ridge moved through Illinois, generating showers and storms. Some of the storms became severe producing damaging winds and large hail.
A disturbance on the periphery of an upper-level ridge moved through Illinois, generating showers and storms. Some of the storms became severe producing damaging winds and large hail.

A strong upper level ridge of high pressure developed across the Ohio and Tennessee Valleys, producing a record-breaking early season heat wave. Along and west of a line from Mount Vernon to Marion to Metropolis, heat index values exceeded 105 degrees starting on June 12 and continuing through June 16. East of that line, heat indices exceeded 105 degrees from the 13th to the 16th. The most oppressive day was June 13, when dewpoints in the mid 70's to around 80 produced heat index values of 110 to 115. Carbondale broke one daily record high temperature and three daily record warm low temperatures. Paducah, KY (across the Ohio River from Metropolis, IL) tied its June all-time warmest low temperature of 81 degrees. This was only the 2nd time on record that Paducah observed four consecutive days reaching 95 degrees this early in the season (before June 20). The other occurrence was back in 1952, with 8 straight days at or above 95 degrees from June 9-16.

Hot and humid conditions developed across northern Illinois during the afternoon of June 13th and continued through the afternoon of June 15th.  High temperatures reached the middle to upper 90s on all three days.  Midway Airport reached 100 degrees on June 14th and June 15th.  The highest heat indices were reached during the afternoon of June 13th and included 115 degrees at Joliet Airport; 114 degrees at Morris Airport; 113 degrees at Peru Airport; 111 degrees at Dixon Airport, Kankakee Airport, Pontiac Airport and Lewis University Airport in Romeoville and 109 degrees at Sugar Grove Airport.  Peak afternoon heat indices reached 105 to 109 degrees on the afternoons of June 14th and June 15th.  A 33 year old man died from heat exposure in Will County on June 14th.

The highest heat indices were reached during the afternoon of June 13th and included 115 degrees at Joliet Airport; 114 degrees at Morris Airport; 113 degrees at Peru Airport; 111 degrees at Dixon Airport, Kankakee Airport, Pontiac Airport and Lewis University Airport in Romeoville and 109 degrees at Sugar Grove Airport.  Peak afternoon heat indices reached 105 to 109 degrees on the afternoons of June 14th and June 15th.  A 33 year old man died from heat exposure in Will County on June 14th.

column37: A utility pole was blown down onto trees along Randall Road.
column38: A supercell thunderstorm moved across northeast Illinois including Chicago and the western suburbs during the late afternoon and early evening of June 13th.  Widespread significant wind damage occurred in many areas and two tornadoes occurred.  Thousands of trees were damaged and hundreds of trees were snapped or uprooted.  Several houses were damaged, some significantly, by falling trees.  Numerous vehicles were damaged or crushed by falling trees or tree limbs.

column37: Trees, tree limbs and power lines were blown down across Westchester.  Some trees were uprooted or snapped.  Some trees fell onto houses and onto vehicles.  Many roads were blocked by fallen trees.  Windows were blown out on the second floor of a vacant office building along Roosevelt Road, causing significant wind damage inside the second floor.  Two apartment buildings along Westchester Boulevard had part of their roofs peeled back with debris blown down to the street.  A three foot diameter soft wood tree nearby was uprooted.  A garage was destroyed near Dickens Street and Newcastle Avenue after a large tree fell on it.  Several houses suffered the loss of roof covering in the area of Mannheim Road and Waterford Drive.  Wind speeds were estimated to 90 mph.

column37: A large tree from a residential backyard fell onto the wall of the Ames School gymnasium but did little to no damage.  The tree fell onto part of the wall with no windows.  The tree also fell onto a chain-link fence, which was damaged and fell onto a power line.
column38: A supercell thunderstorm moved across northeast Illinois including Chicago and the western suburbs during the late afternoon and early evening of June 13th.  Widespread significant wind damage occurred in many areas and two tornadoes occurred.  Thousands of trees were damaged and hundreds of trees were snapped or uprooted.  Several houses were damaged, some significantly, by falling trees.  Numerous vehicles were damaged or crushed by falling trees or tree limbs.

column37: Hundreds of trees were damaged in Riverside, including trees blown down, snapped and uprooted.  Many roads were blocked by fallen trees.  Eight houses were damaged by falling trees, including homes in the 200 and 300 blocks of East Quincy Street.  A large tree was uprooted and fell onto a house on Lawton Road, severely damaging the home.  Utility poles and powerlines were also blown down.  Numerous roads were blocked by fallen trees and tree limbs.  Numerous trees were blown down onto the railroad tracks near the Riverside station.

column37: A 64 year old man was seriously injured when a large tree limb crashed through his windshield near 31st Street and McCormick Avenue. Hot and humid conditions developed across northern Illinois during the afternoon of June 13th and continued through the afternoon of June 15th.  High temperatures reached the middle to upper 90s on all three days.  Midway Airport reached 100 degrees on June 14th and June 15th.  The highest heat indices were reached during the afternoon of June 13th and included 115 degrees at Joliet Airport; 114 degrees at Morris Airport; 113 degrees at Peru Airport; 111 degrees at Dixon Airport, Kankakee Airport, Pontiac Airport and Lewis University Airport in Romeoville and 109 degrees at Sugar Grove Airport.  Peak afternoon heat indices reached 105 to 109 degrees on the afternoons of June 14th and June 15th.  A 33 year old man died from heat exposure in Will County on June 14th.

column37: Trees, tree limbs and power lines were blown down in Antioch.  Some roads were blocked by the fallen trees.
column38: Scattered thunderstorms moved across northern Illinois during the late evening of June 15th into the early morning of June 16th producing isolated wind damage.

column37: A tree was blown down and several tree branches were snapped in Bay View Gardens.
column38: A stationary frontal boundary extending from southern Lake Michigan to northern Missouri triggered a line of strong to severe thunderstorms across north-central Illinois during the early morning of June 16th.  One of the cells within the line became severe, producing wind damage and quarter-sized hail across Woodford County.

column37: A metal pole barn was heavily damaged on Wiedman Road southwest of Cazenovia.
column38: A stationary frontal boundary extending from southern Lake Michigan to northern Missouri triggered a line of strong to severe thunderstorms across north-central Illinois during the early morning of June 16th.  One of the cells within the line became severe, producing wind damage and quarter-sized hail across Woodford County.

A stationary frontal boundary extending from southern Lake Michigan to northern Missouri triggered a line of strong to severe thunderstorms across north-central Illinois during the early morning of June 16th.  One of the cells within the line became severe, producing wind damage and quarter-sized hail across Woodford County.

column37: A few trees and tree branches were blown down at Turtle Lake.
column38: A strong nocturnal low-level jet interacting with a nearly stationary frontal boundary triggered a Mesoscale Convective System (MCS) over northern Missouri during the pre-dawn hours of June 17th.  The large thunderstorm cluster tracked east-southeastward along the boundary, producing significant wind damage and flash flooding.  The storms were focused along and southeast of a Rushville...to Springfield...to Shelbyville...to Robinson line.  Numerous trees and power lines were blown down.  In addition, very heavy rainfall of 3 to 5 inches along and south of a Jacksonville to Effingham line created pockets of flash flooding.

column37: Widespread wind damage across the county. In Shipman and Bunker Hill, numerous large tree limbs as well as several large trees were blown down. In Carlinville, two power poles were snapped off at the base and a large tree was blown over onto a house causing moderate roof damage. About 3 miles west of Girard, multiple mature trees were snapped off near the base, another one was uprooted and a power pole was blown over. A couple of large trees were blown over in Staunton.

column37: There were numerous reports of power outages in Jefferson County. Numerous tree branches and limbs were down in and near Mt. Vernon. Shingles were blown off a few roofs. Large trees were blown down at Dix.
column38: An organized complex of thunderstorms moved southeast across southern Illinois during the early morning hours. The leading edge of the storms was accompanied by strong winds, which resulted in areas of wind damage. The damaging winds were fairly widespread north of the Marion/Carbondale area. Places from Du Quoin and Mount Vernon east to Mount Carmel and Carmi reported pockets of significant wind damage, including roof damage and downed trees and power poles. Further south, damage was mainly confined to isolated tree damage. The combination of mid-level dry air and very moist low levels, characterized by surface dew points in the 70's, produced strong downdrafts. Although deep-layer wind shear was generally less than 25 knots, the established cold pool with the storm complex sustained the surface gust front. An upper-level ridge across the Plains and a trough over the Northeast produced a northwest wind flow that steered early-day thunderstorm clusters into the lower Ohio Valley.

column37: A tornado touched down on Deer Farm Lane near North Passport Road 1 mile south-southeast of Passport at 6:36 AM CDT.  The tornado knocked down multiple power poles, then tracked east-southeastward causing periodic tree damage and damage to the roofing of a barn. The tornado dissipated near the intersection of County Road 1300 North and North Higgin Switch Road about 4.5 miles northwest of Olney at 6:44 AM CDT.

The combination of mid-level dry air and very moist low levels, characterized by surface dew points in the 70's, produced strong downdrafts. Although deep-layer wind shear was generally less than 25 knots, the established cold pool with the storm complex sustained the surface gust front. An upper-level ridge across the Plains and a trough over the Northeast produced a northwest wind flow that steered early-day thunderstorm clusters into the lower Ohio Valley.

column37: Water was flowing across US-40 and US-45 in Effingham.
column38: A strong nocturnal low-level jet interacting with a nearly stationary frontal boundary triggered a Mesoscale Convective System (MCS) over northern Missouri during the pre-dawn hours of June 17th.  The large thunderstorm cluster tracked east-southeastward along the boundary, producing significant wind damage and flash flooding.  The storms were focused along and southeast of a Rushville...to Springfield...to Shelbyville...to Robinson line.  Numerous trees and power lines were blown down.  In addition, very heavy rainfall of 3 to 5 inches along and south of a Jacksonville to Effingham line created pockets of flash flooding.

column38: Several intense clusters of storms moved through eastern Iowa into Illinois. The morning cluster produced flash flooding. column38: A cold front triggered bands of strong to severe thunderstorms across west-central Illinois during the evening of June 25th.  Some of the cells produced wind gusts up to 60mph, resulting in scattered wind damage.  In addition, excessive rainfall rates led to localized flash flooding with some of the stronger storms.

A prolonged heat wave gripped most of southern Illinois for several days. From the 4th to the 8th, peak afternoon heat indices ranged from 105 to 120 degrees. The exception was the Interstate 64 corridor from Mount Vernon to Mount Carmel, where the dangerous levels of heat lasted only from the 4th until the 6th. The hottest day in southern Illinois was the 5th, when the heat index peaked between 111 and 120 at all airport sites. During this heat wave, a sprawling 500 mb high covered most of the southern states from the southern Plains to the southern Appalachian Mountains. Beneath this large 500 mb high, daily high temperatures frequently soared into the mid and upper 90's. Night-time temperatures were quite warm. Carbondale set a daily record warm low temperature of 79 degrees on the 6th.

column37: A private weather station measured 3.75 inches of rain in 84 minutes.
column38: Scattered thunderstorms moved across central Illinois during the afternoon of July 4th producing scattered wind damage and heavy rain.  Isolated thunderstorms moved across parts of northern Illinois during the afternoon of July 4th producing isolated wind damage.  Numerous thunderstorms moved across northern Illinois during the late evening of July 4th and the early morning of July 5th producing wind damage and heavy rain.

column37: The NWS in Chicago relayed a public report of a 12 inch diameter tree down.
column38: Two rounds of storms tracked across portions of  northwest IL on Monday bringing torrential rain, occasional lightning, and gusty winds.  The first round moved through late morning and early afternoon along Interstate 80 from  the Quad Cities, towards Princeton IL.  Rain amounts over 1 inch were common with some totals over 3 inches reported in Bureau county in IL.  This caused some localized flash flooding occurred with these storms.  The second round of storms developed after 7pm across northeast IA and southern WI.  These tracked southeast into northern IL with gusty winds and torrential rain reported.

column37: The Emergency Manager reported that several roads in town were impassable due to high water.

Hot and humid conditions developed across most of northern Illinois during the afternoon of July 5th.  High temperatures were in the mid 90s and afternoon peak heat indices were in the 105 to 110 degree range. Temperatures and heat indices were cooler across far northeast Illinois and near Lake Michigan.

column37: Several thunderstorms moved across McHenry County during the evening of July 5th into the early morning of July 6th producing very heavy rain.  Additional thunderstorms had moved across the same areas a day earlier, from the late evening of July 4th into the early morning of July 5th.  Once the heavy rain began on the evening of July 5th, flooding begin in several locations across south central McHenry County.  Minor ponding of water was reported on Route 120 east of Woodstock.  Significant ponding of water was reported on Route 47 south of Route 176.  Several inches of standing water was reported on Route 23, three miles south of Marengo.  A photo showed multiple feet of standing water at the Illinois Railway Museum in Union.  A nearby private weather station southeast of Union measured 2.25 inches of rain in just 30 minutes and a two day storm total of 6.59 inches of rain.  Many locations in southwest McHenry County received two day rainfall totals between 4 and 7 inches.  A two day total of 5.35 inches was measured in Harvard.  The flooding continued in some areas through much of July 6th.

column38: A line of showers and thunderstorms tracked east northwest Illinois Tuesday evening bringing damaging wind, occasional lightning, and heavy rain.  The strong thunderstorm winds gusts of 60 to 70 MPH were reported at several locations in northwest Illinois.  These winds brought down trees and powerlines as they moved through in the evening.||In addition, heavy rain occurred with the highest amounts over 1 inch common in Jo Daviess and Stephenson counties in IL.

column38: Two rounds of storms tracked across portions of  northwest IL on Monday bringing torrential rain, occasional lightning, and gusty winds.  The first round moved through late morning and early afternoon along Interstate 80 from  the Quad Cities, towards Princeton IL.  Rain amounts over 1 inch were common with some totals over 3 inches reported in Bureau county in IL.  This caused some localized flash flooding occurred with these storms.  The second round of storms developed after 7pm across northeast IA and southern WI.  These tracked southeast into northern IL with gusty winds and torrential rain reported.

column38: A complex of thunderstorms developed along a stalled frontal boundary over Missouri during the pre-dawn hours of July 7, 2022. These storms progressed into Illinois, producing isolated flooding in eastern Illinois during the early afternoon.

column38: A weak low pressure system was located in central Missouri, with a slow moving warm front draped across southern Illinois. Widespread thunderstorms developed along the warm front during the pre-dawn hours, with the complex tracking southeast during the morning. The heaviest rains occurred near and south of I-72, where 2 to 4 inches of rain fell, resulting in a few instances of flash flooding.

column37: Thunderstorm winds blew down several large tree limbs and caused minor siding and shingle damage to a house. Also, a barn sustained minor roof damage.
column38: A cold front moved through the region, triggering showers and storms. Some of the storms became severe producing damaging winds.

column37: Thunderstorm outflow winds snapped a tree, which fell into a home, causing minor structural damage.
column38: Scattered intense thunderstorms fired up during the heat of the day across southern Illinois. This activity developed ahead of a weak cold front and in the vicinity of a weak surface low centered over the mid Mississippi Valley. The atmosphere was quite unstable, with mixed-layer capes from 1500 to 2500 J/kg. Wind shear was sufficiently strong for isolated storms to become severe, with damaging wind gusts. Effective bulk shear was around 30 to 35 knots.

column37: Multiple funnel cloud reports were received from the Northfield and Northbrook areas, including from the O'Hare Airport control tower, an airline pilot and the public.  It appears there was just one well developed funnel cloud that persisted for several minutes and observed by multiple people.
column38: Isolated thunderstorms developed across northeast Illinois during the afternoon of July 11th.  One small supercell thunderstorm produced a funnel cloud and isolated wind damage.

column37: Trees, tree limbs and power lines were blown down in Northfield.  One tree fell onto a house and another tree fell onto a car.  Most of the damage was located in the vicinity of Dickens Road, Riverside Drive, Winnetka Road and Stockton Road.
column38: Isolated thunderstorms developed across northeast Illinois during the afternoon of July 11th.  One small supercell thunderstorm produced a funnel cloud and isolated wind damage.

A man went swimming in Lake Michigan during the evening of July 13th near Jarvis Beach in Chicago.  He was pinned against a break wall by large waves.  Three of his friends used a nearby life ring which they threw to him and were able to help pull him to shore.  Red do not swim flags were flying at the beach and the group had been warned not to enter the water by lifeguards who had just left for the day.  Waves at the nearby Wilmette buoy were 3 to 4 feet and had peaked around 5 feet a few hours earlier.  ||In a separate incident about 24 hours later, on the evening of July 14th, a 14 year old boy was pulled from Lake Michigan at North Avenue Beach in Chicago.  He was taken to a hospital in serious condition.  Waves at the Wilmette Buoy were 2 to 3 feet with northeast wind directions all day.

column38: Showers and storms developed during the afternoon across northwest Illinois. Four funnel clouds were reported with showers and storms near a boundary as it moved across the area during the afternoon hours.

column37: A ten-inch, twenty-foot long tree limb was blown onto a garage.
column38: Short lines of thunderstorms moved east across the Mississippi River. The storms produced isolated wind damage before they weakened east of Interstate 57. The storms occurred along a cold front that extended from central Indiana southwest to the Ozark Mountains of Arkansas. A very moist and unstable air mass supported the storms over Missouri, where mixed-layer cape generally exceeded 2000 j/kg. Southwest 850 mb winds increased to over 30 knots, further aiding storm development. The storms weakened as they outran the more unstable air.

column37: Several trees and large limbs were blown down. A tree fell on a home.
column38: Short lines of thunderstorms moved east across the Mississippi River. The storms produced isolated wind damage before they weakened east of Interstate 57. A very moist and unstable air mass supported the storms over Missouri, where mixed-layer cape generally exceeded 2000 j/kg. Southwest 850 mb winds increased to over 30 knots, further aiding storm development. The storms weakened as they outran the more unstable air.

Heat indices topped 110 degrees across most of southern Illinois in the afternoon. Peak heat indices ranged from 110 at Metropolis to 114 at Carbondale and 116 at Carmi. Along the Interstate 64 corridor, heat indices were a bit lower. Mount Vernon peaked at 109 degrees. A hot and humid southwest wind flow ahead of a cold front brought temperatures up to the mid 90's. Dew points were exceptionally high, with readings in the lower 80's at most stations.

column37: A brief funnel cloud was reported by a trained spotter.
column38: An isolated severe thunderstorm occurred. The thunderstorm occurred in a very moist and unstable southwest wind flow, well in advance of a cold front over the central Plains.

column37: Just off Highway 127 near the Union County line, a large tree and several branches were down. This area is commonly referred to as the Mill Creek area.
column38: An isolated severe thunderstorm occurred. The thunderstorm occurred in a very moist and unstable southwest wind flow, well in advance of a cold front over the central Plains.

column37: A photo was shared of a tree that was blown down onto a car in Lake Bluff.
column38: Isolated thunderstorms moved across far northeast Illinois during the late afternoon and early evening of July 21st.

Another period of excessive heat occurred across southern Illinois. Heat indices peaked around 110 degrees on the 22nd, 23rd, and 24th. The peak heat index at Carbondale was 108 on the 22nd, 105 on the 23rd, and 107 on the 24th. Another large 500 mb high became stubbornly persistent across the southern states, from the Four Corners region to the Southeast. Underneath this high, daily high temperatures were in the lower to mid 90's. Overnight lows were mostly in the mid 70's.

column37: Multiple reports of hail ranging from a half inch to one inch were received from northeast Chicago, including photos shared on social media of quarter size hail from the Irving Park neighborhood.
column38: Thunderstorms developed late in the evening of July 22nd across northeast Illinois and continued into the morning of July 23rd.  Numerous thunderstorms moved over the same areas across portions of Lake County, producing torrential rain and flash flooding.  Large hail also occurred. Three tornadoes occurred in the southern suburbs of Chicago just after sunrise.  Additional thunderstorms developed during the morning and continued into the afternoon of July 23rd, producing isolated large hail and wind damage.

column37: Numerous thunderstorms moved across Lake County during the early morning of July 23rd, producing torrential rain which led to flash flooding across east central portions of the county.  Many roads were flooded and closed in Lake Bluff with several feet of water reported on some roads.  Route 41 was closed between Route 137 and Route 176 where major flooding was reported.  Several vehicles in Lake Bluff, Lake Forest and Highland Park got stuck in the flooding on roadways.  Water rescues were performed along the North Shore.  Basement flooding was reported in the Lake Bluff area.  Interstate 94 was closed near Park Avenue due to flooding.  Route 45 was closed at Casey Road due to flooding.  The Deerfield High School track was flooded with a few feet of water.  Storm total rainfall amounts included 6.68 inches in Lake Bluff; 6.60 inches in Zion; 5.74 inches in Libertyville; 5.54 inches in Lake Forest; 5.12 inches in Deerfield; 4.72 inches in Highwood; 4.34 inches in Mundelein; 4.32 inches in Vernon Hills and 4.26 inches at the Waukegan Airport.

column37: A trained spotter reported a51 knot gust measured by there personal weather station.
column38: Scattered showers and thunderstorms tracked east across eastern Iowa into northwest  Illinois early Saturday morning. Frequent lightning, heavy rain, small hail, and damaging winds downing trees were common as the storms rolled through. Wind gusts between 40 and 60 mph were reported with the storms.

column37: A trained spotter reported damage from wind driven hail at this location. The wind driven hail caused two pieces of siding to fall off along with damage to a window and many dents in the remaining siding.

column37: A tornado with peak winds of 85 mph touched down just north of the DuPage Will County line and moved southeast through the White Eagle Golf Course.  Approximately a dozen golf carts were damaged, several softwood trees were snapped and numerous tree limbs were blown down.  The tornado was likely at peak intensity of 85 mph when it moved through the golf course.  The tornado continued southeast crossing Route 59, just north of 95th Street.  Several small trees were snapped and some roofing material was blown off a shopping plaza at the intersection of Route 59 and 95th Street.  Bleachers were tossed and fencing was blown down near Neuqua Valley High School.  The tornado produced sporadic tree damage as it continued southeast through residential areas, east of Route 59.  The tornado lifted near 119th Street and Book Road.
column38: Thunderstorms developed late in the evening of July 22nd across northeast Illinois and continued into the morning of July 23rd.  Numerous thunderstorms moved over the same areas across portions of Lake County, producing torrential rain and flash flooding.  Large hail also occurred. Three tornadoes occurred in the southern suburbs of Chicago just after sunrise.  Additional thunderstorms developed during the morning and continued into the afternoon of July 23rd, producing isolated large hail and wind damage.

column37: A tornado with peak winds of 70 mph touched down along Pinnacle Drive, just north of Renwick Road.  A construction camera at Lewis University Airport showed the tornado likely lifted then briefly touched down as it moved south into the Prairie Bluff Forest Preserve south of Renwick Road before lifting again.  The tornado touched down again near the Statesville Correctional Center where it caused minor tree damage.  The tornado continued moving south across Caton Farm Road and entered a residential area of Crest Hill.  A concentrated area of damage including several uprooted trees and numerous broken tree limbs was found in the vicinity of Elsie and Highland Avenues.  The tornado paralleled Highland Avenue and Clement Street as it crossed into the far north side of Joliet, where it produced sporadic tree limb damage.  Numerous trees were damaged in the Mount Moriah Cemetery and the tornado lifted just southeast of the cemetery.

As a cold front moved south through the region, showers and storms developed. A few of the storms produced damaging winds and large hail.

column37: Thunderstorm winds blew down several trees, numerous tree limbs, and power lines. Also, a couple of houses sustained minor to moderate damage from the fallen trees and tree limbs.

Scattered thunderstorms developed along an outflow boundary near I-70 during the afternoon. As clusters of storms moved southeast during the evening, additional development behind the initial storms resulted in multiple rounds of thunderstorms over the same areas. More than 4 inches of rain fell in Lawrence County in six hours, producing isolated flash flooding. The storms also produced an isolated strong wind gust.

column37: Flooding on Route 33 south of Russellville.
column38: Scattered thunderstorms developed along an outflow boundary near I-70 during the afternoon. As clusters of storms moved southeast during the evening, additional development behind the initial storms resulted in multiple rounds of thunderstorms over the same areas. column37: Up to 9 inches of rain fell in a 6 to 10 hour period causing widespread flash flooding. The heaviest rain axis extended from East St. Louis southeastward towards Mascoutah. Numerous roads were flooded, including northbound I-55 at I-64, ramps from I-64 to I-255, U.S. Highway 50 between O'Fallon and Lebanon, and Illinois Route 15 near intersection with Frank Scott Parkway.  Several water rescues were performed including on Illinois Route 15 at Karch Road, east of Freeburg and on West F Street near North 3rd Street in Belleville. An estimated 600 St. Clair County households were damaged by flash flooding. The St. Clair County Animal Shelter was flooded in Belleville so several dozen dogs and some cats had to be evacuated and placed in other shelters or homes temporarily. Overall, no injuries were reported in St. Clair County.
column38: During the early morning of Tuesday, July 26th, 2022, a complex of training thunderstorms set up roughly along the I-70 corridor in Missouri and I-64 corridor in Illinois. Several rounds of thunderstorms with rainfall rates exceeding 2in/hr affected this area, including the St. Louis metropolitan area, through the early hours of July 26th and into the morning commute. Upwards of 11 of rain fell over the course of roughly 8 hours in an axis from Hawk Point, MO to St. Peters, MO according to radar-estimated rainfall products and several CoCoRaHS/spotter reports. A longer axis of over 8 of rain fell from northern Montgomery County in Missouri to St. Clair County in Illinois, causing multiple swift water rescues and scores of flooded interstates and homes across the St. Louis metropolitan area. St. Louis-Lambert International Airport also observed a new all-time record for daily precipitation: 8.64 of rain fell since midnight Central Standard Time (Daylight Savings Time is not used for climatological record-keeping). This value broke the previous record of 6.85, which occurred on August 20th, 1915 due to the remnants of the Galveston 1915 Hurricane. The storm-total rainfall was 9.07, but spans two days. Two fatalities were reported: one in St. Louis City, where a man drowned in his car near Skinker Blvd, and another in Hazelwood where a man drowned attempting to flee his flooded truck.

column37: Up to 6 inches of rain fell in 6 to 10 hour period causing flash flooding across the northern portions of Bond County. Several roads in this area were flooded. About a mile south of Donnellson, one vehicle was washed off the roadway. The driver was rescued and sustained no injuries.

column37: Up to 7 inches of rain fell between a 6 and 10 hour period causing widespread flash flooding. Numerous roads were flooded. In Nashville, the secondary dam on the Nashville City Reservoir sustained a 6 foot wide breach due to the heavy rainfall. The water from the secondary dam flowed south flooding Illinois Route 15 on the east side of town. No homes were affected, but a couple of businesses had water surrounding them. The nearby Nashville Memorial Park baseball fields were flooded due to the dam breach.

column37: Street flooding was reported by the public west of Mount Vernon. Between 3 and 4 inches of rain was measured at several sites in western and central Jefferson County.
column38: A complex of thunderstorms moved east across parts of southern Illinois through the morning. Training of heavy rain resulted in widespread 2 to 4 inches of rainfall along the Interstate 64 corridor. The persistent thunderstorms were focused along a stalled elevated warm front across the mid Mississippi Valley. Strong convergence in the 925 to 850 mb layer was oriented generally parallel to the mean storm movement. Instability of at least 500-1500 J/kg just south of the training storms supported high rainfall rates.

column37: Several miles southeast of Marion, trees and large limbs were down. There was shingle damage to a house. Several trees were snapped. A greenhouse was flipped and rolled. The hvac unit of a house was moved off its concrete pad a few feet.
column38: A complex of thunderstorms moved east across southern Illinois during the early morning hours. A few of the storms became severe. The complex of storms occurred along a cold front that extended from the Great Lakes to the mid Mississippi Valley. The storms occurred along the southern fringe of a band of stronger 500 mb winds in a region of weak to moderate instability. Due to moist ground from previous thunderstorms, some roads were flooded.

column37: Several trees were down between Norris City and Omaha.

column37: Up to three inches fell in a 4 hour period causing flash flooding. Numerous roads were flooded across the northern half of St. Clair County, including Main Street at West Highway 50 in O'Fallon, Illinois Route 15 at Belleville West Parkway, and northbound I-55/I-70 in East St. Louis. Several families had to be rescued from their homes due to the flash flooding, including one on State Street and one on Terrace Drive in East St. Louis. No injuries were reported.
column38: A cluster of showers and thunderstorms, extending from St. Louis metro area to southeastern Missouri, moved eastward through the afternoon and early evening hours. With precipitable water values over 2 inches and warm cloud depths up to 14,000 feet thick, these storms produced very heavy rainfall, up to five inches, in a short period of time, between 2 pm and 7 pm on July 28th. Also, the soil in the area was quite saturated due to the catastrophic flash flooding two days prior. This caused another round of flash flooding in portions of St. Louis County, St. Louis city, Jefferson County in Missouri and St. Clair County in Illinois.

column37: Standing water partially covered Route 150.
column38: A large complex of thunderstorms moved east across southern Illinois during the afternoon and evening hours. Very heavy rainfall rates contributed to isolated instances of flash flooding. The complex of thunderstorms developed ahead of a 500 mb disturbance over central Missouri, which moved eastward into a very moist and unstable air mass. Precipitable water values were around 2.25 inches, and surface-based cape exceeded 2000 J/kg. Soils across the region were quite moist due to repeated thunderstorms in the preceding several days.

column37: Several roads were flooded. At least one car was stuck in floodwaters.
column38: A large complex of thunderstorms moved east across southern Illinois during the afternoon and evening hours. Very heavy rainfall rates contributed to isolated instances of flash flooding. A cold front extending from Wisconsin into eastern Iowa triggered a line of strong to severe thunderstorms during the pre-dawn hours of August 1st.  The storms tracked southeastward, producing scattered wind damage along and north of the I-72 corridor.  One of the cells spawned a brief EF-1 tornado in the town of Beason in eastern Logan County which severely damaged a grain elevator and numerous trees before quickly lifting.  Another storm produced a brief EF-0 tornado near Mason City in Mason County that caused minor damage.

A surface low moving across Minnesota and Wisconsin drug a cold front across northwest Illinois during the early morning hours of August 1st. Showers and thunderstorms developed across the area ahead of the front.  There was sufficient shear and instability for these storms to produce sporadic hail up to an inch and an isolated damaging wind gust.

column37: A tornado touched down in a field just north of County Road 1300 North about 2.5 miles north of Mason City at 4:46 AM CDT.  The tornado tracked southeastward toward the intersection of County Road 1300 North and County Road 3600 East, flipping an empty trailer hopper and damaging a tractor before quickly dissipating at 4:48 AM CDT.

column37: A tornado touched down on the far west side of Beason at 5:12 AM CDT.  It damaged a grain elevator, some large bins, and equipment on the west end of Clinton Street...then tracked southeastward, damaging numerous trees and powerlines on the west end of County Road 1549 North and near the intersection of County Road 2143 East and County Road 1540 North.  A few homes along the track had minor roof damage and missing shingles, while one suffered a broken window.  The tornado continued southeastward through corn fields before lifting about 1.75 miles southeast of Beason at 5:15 AM CDT.

column37: Three trees were blown down and a gazebo was tossed onto the roof of a house, causing damage to the roof.
column38: A cold front extending from Wisconsin into eastern Iowa triggered a line of strong to severe thunderstorms during the pre-dawn hours of August 1st.  The storms tracked southeastward, producing scattered wind damage along and north of the I-72 corridor.  One of the cells spawned a brief EF-1 tornado in the town of Beason in eastern Logan County which severely damaged a grain elevator and numerous trees before quickly lifting.  Another storm produced a brief EF-0 tornado near Mason City in Mason County that caused minor damage.

Hazardous levels of heat and humidity occurred, mainly along and west of Interstate 57.   Afternoon heat indices peaked between 105 and 109 degrees. The peak heat index ranged from 105 degrees at Carbondale to 109 degrees at the Williamson County airport. The heat occurred under a brisk southwest wind flow between high pressure over the central Gulf coast and low pressure over the upper Great Lakes.

An outflow boundary from convection earlier in the day served as the primary focusing mechanism for numerous storm clusters along and south of I-70 from the late afternoon  of August 1st into the pre-dawn hours of August 2nd.  Some of the storms dropped very large hail up to 2 inches in diameter.  In addition, continuous back-building cells produced a swath of heavy rainfall in excess of 8 inches from eastern Effingham County across Jasper County into northeastern Richland County.  As a result, many roads were closed due to flash flooding.  The flooding lingered until around midday on August 2nd, particularly in the hardest hit locations from Dietrich in Effingham County to Newton in Jasper County.

column37: A severe thunderstorm produced a narrow swath of large hail west through south of Mt. Carmel. Ping-pong ball size hail was reported on Highway 15 just east of Bellmont. Quarter-size hail was reported on the south side of Mt. Carmel near the power plant.
column38: Small clusters of strong to severe thunderstorms moved southeast across the lower Wabash Valley during the late afternoon and evening hours. Large hail was reported with a couple of these storms. The storms initially formed along the residual outflow boundary left by an early morning thunderstorm complex. The atmosphere was very unstable during the late afternoon and early evening, when peak mixed-layer capes approached 4000 J/kg. Once the storms formed an organized cold pool, new thunderstorms developed on the western flank of the storm complex as an unstable southwest wind flow was lifted over the cold pool.

A persistent frontal boundary draped across central Illinois continued to be the focus for strong to severe thunderstorm development during the morning of August 2nd.  A low-level jet interacting with the boundary triggered the first cluster of storms across portions of Sangamon and Logan counties during the pre-dawn hours, with additional cells forming from Galesburg to near Lawrenceville as the morning progressed.  The storms gradually dissipated and shifted east of the region by early afternoon.  Scattered wind damage and flash flooding occurred.

column38: Localized flooding occurred in association with a thunderstorm complex over southeast Illinois and the lower Wabash Valley. Numerous showers and thunderstorms occurred on the leading edge of a southwest wind flow of warm and moist air. High pressure over the central Gulf coast states combined with low pressure over the upper Missouri Valley resulted in the southwest wind flow.

A low-level jet interacting with the boundary triggered the first cluster of storms across portions of Sangamon and Logan counties during the pre-dawn hours, with additional cells forming from Galesburg to near Lawrenceville as the morning progressed.  The storms gradually dissipated and shifted east of the region by early afternoon.  Scattered wind damage and flash flooding occurred.

column37: Minor flooding occurred on the Little Wabash River. Low-lying woods and fields were underwater, including cropland. Some county roads were inundated.
column38: Minor flooding occurred on the Little Wabash River. An active pattern was in place as August began, fueled by above normal temperatures and ample humidity on generally southerly surface winds. Several rounds of thunderstorms from the 2nd to the 7th pushed the river above flood stage.

column38: A weak surface low and its attendant cold front moved into northwest Illinois on the morning of August 3rd. A line of storms developed ahead of the front and one of these storms produced damaging winds as it moved across Stephenson County.

Another round of hazardous heat and humidity occurred, affecting all but the southeast corner from Massac to Hardin County. Afternoon heat indices peaked around 105 degrees. Specific readings included 106 at Marion, 109 at Mount Vernon, and 108 at Carmi. The heat occurred under a strong southwest wind flow ahead of a cold front over the central Plains.

column37: Thunderstorm winds blew a road sign over near the north bound lanes of I-55 about 4 miles north of Farmersville. Also, a semi was blown over on I-55 just north of Farmersville. No injuries were reported.
column38: During the afternoon hours of August 3rd, numerous thunderstorms developed across parts of eastern Missouri and west-central Illinois, triggered by strong surface heating ahead of a surging outflow boundary. These storms developed within a strongly unstable environment, featuring MLCAPE values ranging from 2500 to as much as 4000 J/kg and largely driven by the very warm and humid boundary layer. The initial round of storms struggled to become organized. Eventually cold pool interactions drove upscale growth into a more linear complex. Damaging winds, occasional large hail were reported as well as bursts of very heavy rain rates. By the evening of August 3rd, storms grew upscale, with additional rounds of thunderstorms developing upstream from this initial activity. The primary hazard transitioned from a damaging wind threat to a heavy rain and flash flooding threat, as storms were extremely efficient rain producers. Warm cloud depths were around 4.5km, along with anomalously high precipitable water values of 2 to 2.5 inches, and Corfidi vector orientations that supported westward back-building which enhanced the potential for locally heavy rain, both in terms of instantaneous rates (2+ inches per hour at times) and training of storms. By mid morning on August 4th, widespread rainfall amounts of 1 to 3 inches fell, mainly along and south of I-70 in Missouri and along and east of I-55 in Illinois. Over the St. Louis metro area, as well as Fredericktown, MO, between 4 and 7 inches of rain fell. There were numerous reports of flash flooding in these areas.

column37: Thunderstorm winds blew down several trees near the intersection of 4th Street and Henry Street. Also a large tree was blown over into the front yard, narrowly missing the house. Numerous tree limbs and power lines were blown down around town, including in Oakwood Cemetery.

A line of thunderstorms developed near I-55 along an outflow boundary during early afternoon and progressed east-southeast towards I-70 by early evening. The storms produced scattered wind damage, and a 61 mph gust was measured at the Decatur Airport. Heavy rain led to a few instances of flash flooding near the I-70 corridor during the evening.

column37: There was flowing water four to five inches deep on Charleston Avenue near 21st Street.
column38: A line of thunderstorms developed near I-55 along an outflow boundary during early afternoon and progressed east-southeast towards I-70 by early evening. The storms produced scattered wind damage, and a 61 mph gust was measured at the Decatur Airport. Heavy rain led to a few instances of flash flooding near the I-70 corridor during the evening.

column37: Thunderstorm winds snapped off a large tree at the ground in New Baden. In Aviston, numerous tree limbs were blown down. Also, the tin roof of an outhouse was ripped off.
column38: During the afternoon hours of August 3rd, numerous thunderstorms developed across parts of eastern Missouri and west-central Illinois, triggered by strong surface heating ahead of a surging outflow boundary. These storms developed within a strongly unstable environment, featuring MLCAPE values ranging from 2500 to as much as 4000 J/kg and largely driven by the very warm and humid boundary layer. The initial round of storms struggled to become organized. Eventually cold pool interactions drove upscale growth into a more linear complex. Damaging winds, occasional large hail were reported as well as bursts of very heavy rain rates. By the evening of August 3rd, storms grew upscale, with additional rounds of thunderstorms developing upstream from this initial activity. The primary hazard transitioned from a damaging wind threat to a heavy rain and flash flooding threat, as storms were extremely efficient rain producers. Warm cloud depths were around 4.5km, along with anomalously high precipitable water values of 2 to 2.5 inches, and Corfidi vector orientations that supported westward back-building which enhanced the potential for locally heavy rain, both in terms of instantaneous rates (2+ inches per hour at times) and training of storms. By mid morning on August 4th, widespread rainfall amounts of 1 to 3 inches fell, mainly along and south of I-70 in Missouri and along and east of I-55 in Illinois. Over the St. Louis metro area, as well as Fredericktown, MO, between 4 and 7 inches of rain fell. There were numerous reports of flash flooding in these areas.

column37: There were numerous reports of street flooding in Marion. Significant street flooding occurred across the city of Johnston City, where over four inches of rain fell from midnight to late morning. Poor Farm Road was washed out north of Johnston City, leaving a trench large enough to swallow a car. On the north side of Marion, fire and rescue crews assisted residents of a flooded trailer park. The park was entirely flooded, and some residents were advised to remain indoors. Main Street on the east side of the Marion square was nearly impassable. A Marion day care center was evacuated due to flooding. Several inches of water were in the classrooms and hallway. A Cocorahs observer at Marion measured 5.63 inches in a 48-hour period.
column38: A small but nearly stationary cluster of thunderstorms occurred ahead of a cold front extending from Lake Michigan down across central Missouri. Flash flooding occurred under this stationary cluster of storms.

column37: Significant flash flooding was reported across the western side of Franklin County. Water was over Route 14 in multiple locations west of Christopher. Water was over Route 184 in multiple locations north and south of Mulkeytown. Many rural roads were completely impassable. A Cocorahs observer at Christopher measured 5.11 inches of rain over 48 hours.
column38: A very small but stationary cluster of thunderstorms sat over the same area during the early morning hours. Isolated flash flooding occurred under this cluster. These storms were associated with a weak cold front that extended from Lake Michigan down into southeast Illinois.

column37: The Emergency Manager reports that 6 hour rainfall has been 4 to 8 inches. They also reported that flood waters have moved into the road maintenance shed for the city of Freeport. Additionally, there were two roads washed out in county as well as widespread reports of water on area roadways. The time of the event was estimated using radar.
column38: Two rounds of showers and thunderstorms tracked from northeast Iowa into northern Illinois Sunday morning, and again early Monday morning, bringing torrential rain and occasional lightning to the region.  Rainfall amounts over 2 inches were common northeast of a line from Cedar Rapids, to De Witt, to Prophetstown IL.  The highest amounts between 5 and 11 inches fell in eastern Jo Daviess and Stephenson counties in northwest IL.  This caused numerous road closures in the county and floodwaters impacting homes in Freeport, IL.

column37: Flooding caused 167th Street to be closed.  Side roads were likely flooded as well.  Rainfall of 3.06 inches was measured in Oak Forest.
column38: Scattered thunderstorms produced heavy rain during the morning and afternoon of August 7th, which caused localized flooding.

column37: Water was reported over Karlov Road.

column37: Some backyards were under nearly one foot of water and widespread basement flooding was reported.
column38: Heavy rain caused flash flooding across parts of northwest Illinois during the morning of August 8th when rainfall of 3 to 5 inches with locally higher amounts fell.  Previous rainfall the day before brought two day rainfall totals to 6 to 9 inches across many areas across northwest Illinois.  A church was struck by lightning in Rockford during the morning of August 8th causing significant damage.  Rockford Airport measured a two day rain total of 6.15 inches for August 7th and 8th with 3.23 inches on August 8th which set a new rain record for the day.

A 45 year old man was pulled from Lake Michigan near Grant Park in the early evening of August 11th.  The man was taken to a hospital in critical condition where he died.  North winds allowed waves to build to around 4 feet at the nearby Chicago buoy.

Dense fog formed across parts of southern Illinois during the overnight hours and burned off early in the morning. The dense fog was mainly along and south of a line from the Marion-Carbondale area to Harrisburg. Visibility was at or below one-quarter mile. The fog formed under a light northeast wind flow from high pressure over the upper Mississippi Valley.

A cold core low moved over the area, dragging along a weak and slow moving surface low. Although weak, sufficient low level and upper forcing aided in developing strong to severe storms. Instability and shear were strong enough for a few supercell thunderstorms to develop and bring hail, strong winds, and heavy rain to the area. The storms were slow moving. which allowed some storms to anchor over locations for an extended period of time, resulting in flash flooding. Some repeated storms over the same area also led to similar results. Severe weather reports were mostly in the form of hail, as these storms produced hail very efficiently. The largest hail reported was 1.5, and there were some isolated reports of damaging winds.

column37: A chaser reported that a funnel cloud lasted 2 minutes at this location and eventually touched down briefly. There is photo and eyewitness evidence of the brief ground based rotation. The tornado is rated an EF-U.
column38: The cold core low that moved into the area on August 19th lingered into the 20th.  Sufficient instability and shear were present for the formation of many mini supercells that led to many funnel cloud reports with a couple of brief tornado touch downs.

column37: Eyewitness reports along with video and photographic evidence from storm chasers support an intermittent tornado path of nearly 3 miles. There are also reports of minor crop damage associated with tornado. Times were based on detailed information from chasers. With no observable damage to assess, this tornado is rated an EF-U.

column37: Quarter sized hail mixed with smaller hail.
column38: Supercells formed in the early afternoon near Peoria, to the southeast of a surface low over eastern Iowa and out ahead of its associated cold front. Storms produced large hail, damaging winds, and heavy rain leading to isolated flash flooding. The strongest storm impacted Tazewell County, producing hail as large as three inches in diameter and rainfall amounts of four to five inches. Into the evening, storms transitioned into a cluster that progressed east, producing sporadic small hail and continued heavy rainfall.

column37: Several large trees were down. One tree was snapped near the base. Several others lost large limbs.
column38: Isolated thunderstorms occurred in a moist and unstable air mass ahead of a slow-moving cold front. The front extended from Lake Michigan southwest to the Ozark Plateau of southwest Missouri when a storm produced isolated tree damage in southern Illinois.
A cold front moved through the region. Showers and storms associated with it produced a few reports of damaging winds and large hail.

column38: An intense disturbance lifted across eastern Iowa and northwest Illinois during the late morning and early afternoon hours of the 28th. Peeks of sunshine during the morning fueled sufficient instability and shear for isolated severe thunderstorms that produced damaging wind gusts in Carroll and Stephenson Counties.

column38: An isolated severe thunderstorm drifted slowly over west central Hamilton County, producing large hail. This storm and other scattered thunderstorms developed during the heat of the day ahead of a cold front. Some of the storms produced torrential rain, which resulted in an isolated flash flood event. The cold front trailed southwest from a low pressure center over the Great Lakes region across northern Illinois and central Missouri.

column37: The broadcast media relayed a photo of the hailstone next to a quarter for reference.
column38: An isolated severe thunderstorm drifted slowly over west central Hamilton County, producing large hail. This storm and other scattered thunderstorms developed during the heat of the day ahead of a cold front. Some of the storms produced torrential rain, which resulted in an isolated flash flood event. The cold front trailed southwest from a low pressure center over the Great Lakes region across northern Illinois and central Missouri.

column37: A tree was blown down across Route 97 south of Salisbury.
column38: Numerous clusters of strong thunderstorms developed along an outflow boundary and ahead of a slowly approaching cold front during the evening of August 29th.  Some of the thunderstorm cells merged and produced damaging wind gusts in excess of 60mph, particularly across Vermilion County.  Excessive rainfall rates led to scattered flash flooding across central Illinois as well.

column37: Extensive urban flooding was reported across Decatur.  Several streets were closed due to high water.  Vehicles were stranded in flood waters, requiring a few water rescues.
column38: A slowly approaching cold front triggered numerous clusters of thunderstorms across central Illinois during the evening of September 3rd into the early morning of September 4th.  Some of the storms produced locally heavy rainfall of 2 to 3 inches and isolated flash flooding.  The hardest hit location was Decatur, where widespread street flooding occurred.

column37: Standing water was reported on eastbound Interstate 64 between Woodlawn and Mt. Vernon, as well as southbound Interstate 57 at the Interstate 64 interchange south of Mt. Vernon. Both spots are typical flood-prone areas.
column38: Isolated thunderstorms formed in the vicinity of a mid-level trough that extended from the Great Lakes region down across the mid-Mississippi Valley. An inverted surface trough from the lower Mississippi Valley to the lower Ohio Valley provided additional support. Locally heavy rain in the slow-moving storms resulted in isolated minor flooding.

column37: Up to five inches of rain fell in a short amount of time, especially in the Lake Glenn Shoals and Irving areas. Several roads were flooded including Illinois Route 16 just northeast of Irving. A vehicle was driven into the flood waters and stalled in this area. The driver was rescued and no injuries were reported.
column38: An upper level system stalled out over the region with plenty of low level moisture convergence on the nose of a modest low level jet. The forcing was focused over south central Illinois, so this is the area that got the most rainfall. A couple of isolated areas had over 4 inches of rain in a short amount of time, causing flash flooding.

column37: Water was flowing across roads in Forsyth.
column38: Several waves of low pressure tracking along a nearly stationary frontal boundary draped along I-70 triggered a band of showers and thunderstorms across central Illinois during the afternoon of September 4th.  The band developed along I-72 and produced rainfall of 1.50 to 2.50.  With thunderstorms the night before already saturating the ground, this additional rainfall led to isolated flash flooding across parts of Macon County.

column37: A photo shared on social media showed a healthy 9 inch diameter tree limb snapped near Cheshire Court and Canton Drive.
column38: Scattered thunderstorms produced heavy rain during the morning of September 11th.  A narrow swath of torrential rain fell across portions of the north side of Chicago causing widespread flash flooding and at least 2,000 basements to flood.  Rainfall amounts of 2 to 4 inches were common across much of northern Illinois with a heavier swath of 4 to 6 inches over northwest Illinois and over northeast Illinois including central DuPage and central Cook Counties.

column37: Photos shared on social media showed portions of Hummer Park were flooded from the north branch of St. Joseph Creek.  The park was designed to flood in heavy rain events.  Rainfall of 4.78 inches was measured in Downers Grove with 2.87 inches falling in one hour ending at 7:45 am CST.

column37: A supercell thunderstorm moved across portions of central Cook County and the north side of Chicago producing a narrow swath of torrential rainfall with amounts of 4 to 6 inches.  Flash flooding developed across many areas with streets quickly becoming flooded which numerous stranded vehicles in the flood waters.  A car was stuck in flood waters in the 4800 block of Ravenswood Avenue where a woman and two children were rescued.  Significant flooding occurred along Foster, Lawrence and Bryn Mawr Avenues where cars were stalled in flood waters and some drivers needed to be rescued.  A car was stuck in a flooded viaduct at 1800 Foster Avenue.  A car was stuck in a flooded viaduct at Foster Avenue and Lake Shore Drive.  A car was stuck in flood waters in the 2700 block of Diversey Avenue.  A photo was shared on social media showing three cars stuck in flood waters near Irving Park Road and Kilbourne Avenue.  Numerous residential streets were flooded with 1 to 2 feet of standing water.  A nursing home was flooded along Western Avenue.  An estimated 2,000 basements suffered some amount of flooding.  Water was seen shooting up from various sewers which was likely due to pressure differences in the vast sewer system and the localized nature of the heaviest rain.||The highest rainfall totals included 5.90 inches in Lincoln Square where about 4 inches fell in 75 minutes ending at 8:55 am CST; 5.86 inches in Portage Park where about 3.4 inches fell in one hour ending at 8:30 am CST and 5.63 inches in Albany Park where about 3.5 inches fell in one hour ending at 8:40 am CST.||The City of Chicago reported 8 homes suffered major water damage resulting in $84,000 in damages; 309 homes suffered minor water damage resulting in $2,519,000 in damages and 52 businesses suffered minor water damage resulting in $503,000 in damages.  Damage amounts were unknown for the remaining affected homes as well as vehicles that were affected by flooding.

Severe thunderstorms developed across portions of eastern Iowa, northwest Illinois, and far northeast Missouri on the evening of September 18, 2022. Storms initially developed near the Iowa/Missouri border, with one storm near Bloomfield IA producing a well defined wall cloud before weakening. Storms developed and increased in strength just east of the Cedar Rapids and Iowa City metros as they slowly tracked east around the Interstate 80 corridor. Several large hail reports were received around Durant to south of Tipton, with the largest report being 2.5 inches. Storms also produced small hail and wind damage in the Quad Cities before spreading southeast into Henry County IL. Additional storms developed along the Iowa/Missouri/Illinois tri-state area, with several tornado warnings issued. Damage was reported in southern Hancock County near Tioga, and continued south into Adams County, although no tornadoes were confirmed.

A cold front interacting with a warm and humid airmass triggered several clusters of strong to severe thunderstorms across parts of central Illinois during the evening of September 18th into the early morning of September 19th.  The storms were concentrated along and north of I-74 and along and southwest of a Rushville to Springfield line.  Many of the storms produced wind damage and large hail, with the largest 2.5 inch-diameter hailstones being observed in Mahomet in Champaign County.  In addition, an EF-0 tornado touched down near LeRoy in McLean County causing minor roof damage and knocking down several trees and power poles.

Many of the storms produced wind damage and large hail, with the largest 2.5 inch-diameter hailstones being observed in Mahomet in Champaign County.  In addition, an EF-0 tornado touched down near LeRoy in McLean County causing minor roof damage and knocking down several trees and power poles.

column37: A tornado touched down on the southwest side of LeRoy at 12:28am CDT, knocking a power pole onto a mobile home and a tree onto another mobile home.  The tornado tracked southeastward through the southern part of town doing minor tree damage, causing partial roof damage to two duplexes, and tipping over two semis on I-74.  It continued southeastward, partially damaging a roof 2.5 miles southeast of LeRoy before dissipating in a field about 3.5 miles southeast of LeRoy at 12:34am CDT.

Moderate drought conditions developed in September in the southern tip of Illinois, generally south of a line from Carbondale to Harrisburg. Far southern Illinois experienced an abnormally dry month, ranking in the top 10 driest Septembers on record. Some areas from Carbondale southward struggled to pick up an inch of rain the entire month. At Carbondale, September was the 9th driest September on record. The monthly rainfall at Carbondale was 0.69 inch, which resulted in a deficit of 2.16 inches below normal. Field and brush fire danger increased as grass turned brown. Bans on outdoor burning were initiated in a couple of counties by the end of the month. The dry weather occurred too late to have a major impact on crop yields. Crops were nearing harvest when the drought developed.

Drought conditions gradually worsened through the last week of the month. The drought severity was greatest in the southernmost three counties from Cairo to Metropolis, where it became extreme. Further north, the drought became severe as far north as the Marion, Carbondale, and Benton areas. Elsewhere, the drought was classified as moderate, including the Interstate 64 corridor. Most crops were in the process of being harvested, so agricultural impacts were very limited. However, pastures were in poor or very poor condition. This forced farmers to begin feeding hay to cattle, which was likely to become in short supply in the winter months. Stock ponds ran low or completely dried up. The wildfire danger rose to critical levels on a few days where windy conditions coincided with very low humidity. Bans on outdoor burning were imposed in much of the region. Near Mt. Vernon, about 80 acres of a soybean field burned on October 14. A large field fire near Brookport, IL in Massac County occurred on October 24. This 78-acre fire destroyed a barn before being brought under control. Some locally beneficial rain arrived at the end of the month. Even so, most locations were still 3 to over 6 inches below normal on rainfall since September 1. One of the most significant impacts was very low water levels on the Mississippi and Ohio Rivers. Parts of the Mississippi River reached all-time low levels, nearly forcing the river transportation industry to a halt. Dredging helped restore navigation channels to a depth sufficiently deep for river traffic to resume in a limited capacity. Tower Rock, normally inaccessible by foot traffic, became easily reachable on foot when the Mississippi River dropped to record or near record low levels. The city of Cairo was forced to change its water source from the Ohio River to groundwater. The Ohio River level dropped below the level of its water intake pipes.

Tower Rock, normally inaccessible by foot traffic, became easily reachable on foot when the Mississippi River dropped to record or near record low levels. The city of Cairo was forced to change its water source from the Ohio River to groundwater. The Ohio River level dropped below the level of its water intake pipes.

Drought conditions gradually worsened through the last week of the month. The drought severity was greatest in the southernmost three counties from Cairo to Metropolis, where it became extreme. Further north, the drought became severe as far north as the Marion, Carbondale, and Benton areas. Elsewhere, the drought was classified as moderate, including the Interstate 64 corridor. Most crops were in the process of being harvested, so agricultural impacts were very limited. However, pastures were in poor or very poor condition. This forced farmers to begin feeding hay to cattle, which was likely to become in short supply in the winter months. Stock ponds ran low or completely dried up. The wildfire danger rose to critical levels on a few days where windy conditions coincided with very low humidity. Bans on outdoor burning were imposed in much of the region. Near Mt. Vernon, about 80 acres of a soybean field burned on October 14. A large field fire near Brookport, IL in Massac County occurred on October 24. This 78-acre fire destroyed a barn before being brought under control. Some locally beneficial rain arrived at the end of the month. Even so, most locations were still 3 to over 6 inches below normal on rainfall since September 1. One of the most significant impacts was very low water levels on the Mississippi and Ohio Rivers. The first freeze of the season brought an end to the growing season. Low temperatures were from 28 to 32 degrees. A strong 1032 mb high pressure center over the Dakotas produced a brisk northerly wind flow of chilly air.

Severe to extreme drought persisted over much of southern Illinois through November.   The drought severity was greatest in the southernmost three counties from Cairo to Metropolis, where it remained extreme. The drought was severe as far north and east as the Marion, Harrisburg, and Benton areas. Elsewhere, the drought was classified as moderate from the Wabash Valley to Wayne and Gallatin Counties. Most crops had been harvested, so agricultural impacts were limited. However, pastures were in poor or very poor condition. This forced farmers to begin feeding hay to cattle, which is normally reserved for the winter months. Stock ponds ran low or completely dried up. Wildfire danger remained high at times during the month. However, periodic light rainfalls allowed all counties to lift bans on outdoor burning. Even so, rainfall deficits were still 4 to 7 inches below normal for the fall (September 1 to November 30). One of the most significant impacts was very low water levels on the Mississippi and Ohio Rivers. Parts of the Mississippi River reached all-time low levels, however rain improved river levels sufficiently for navigation to fully resume by the end of the month.

Dense fog reduced visibility to one-quarter mile or less over southern Illinois during the early morning hours. High pressure extending from the central Gulf coast through the Tennessee and lower Ohio Valleys resulted in conditions favorable for the fog.

Severe to extreme drought persisted over much of southern Illinois through November.   The drought severity was greatest in the southernmost three counties from Cairo to Metropolis, where it remained extreme. The drought was severe as far north and east as the Marion, Harrisburg, and Benton areas. Elsewhere, the drought was classified as moderate from the Wabash Valley to Wayne and Gallatin Counties. Most crops had been harvested, so agricultural impacts were limited. However, pastures were in poor or very poor condition. This forced farmers to begin feeding hay to cattle, which is normally reserved for the winter months. Stock ponds ran low or completely dried up. Wildfire danger remained high at times during the month. However, periodic light rainfalls allowed all counties to lift bans on outdoor burning. Even so, rainfall deficits were still 4 to 7 inches below normal for the fall (September 1 to November 30). One of the most significant impacts was very low water levels on the Mississippi and Ohio Rivers. Parts of the Mississippi River reached all-time low levels, however rain improved river levels sufficiently for navigation to fully resume by the end of the month.

Dense fog reduced visibility to one-quarter mile or less over southern Illinois during the early morning hours. High pressure extending from the central Gulf coast through the Tennessee and lower Ohio Valleys resulted in conditions favorable for the fog.

A strong storm system brought much needed rainfall to northwest Illinois the morning of November 4th through the 5th. This also brought two rounds of severe weather to northwest Illinois. The morning of November 4th, a few storms cells intensified quickly and produced isolated hail reports ranging from quarter to ping pong ball sized. Heavy rain also fell with this storm system with 48 hour rainfall totals of 0.5 to 1.5 inches across northwest Illinois with the heaviest rains reported north of a Clinton Iowa to Freeport Illinois.

Strong south winds gusted from 40 up to around 50 mph. The highest measured wind gust was 51 mph at the Carbondale airport. Other notable wind gusts included 48 mph at the Harrisburg airport, 47 mph at the Marion airport, and 43 mph at the Cairo and Mount Vernon airports. In Herrin, a tree fell and crushed a fence in a residential area. In Marion, part of a large tree limb went through a home. The strong south winds occurred ahead of a cold front that trailed south from a low pressure center over the upper Mississippi Valley.

column37: A grain elevator and several power lines were damaged in the town of Kansas due to non-thunderstorm winds gusting up to 60mph.
column38: A deepening area of low pressure tracking from northern Missouri to southern Wisconsin pulled a cold front through central Illinois during the morning of November 5th.  Strong southerly winds gusting over 50mph ahead of the front produced scattered wind damage.    In addition, a narrow line of showers with a few embedded thunderstorms immediately along the front was able to tap into higher momentum air aloft, resulting in a few wind gusts in excess of 60mph along the line.  The highest wind gusts were generally concentrated along and north of I-72, with Willard Airport in Champaign measuring a peak gust of 68mph.

column37: A tree was blown down on Dee Bennett Road and another tree was blown down along Route 52, both in LaSalle County.
column38: A strong cold front moved across northern Illinois during the late morning and early afternoon of November 5th with convective showers which produced thunderstorm wind damage and one tornado.  Wind damage from the convection was described as countywide across Ogle, Boone and McHenry Counties.  DuPage Airport measured a peak wind gust to 77 mph.  A handheld anemometer measured a wind gust to 80 mph near Roselle.||High winds caused tree damage both in the early morning of November 5th and then again in the afternoon of November 5th.  A large portion of a roof was blown off an apartment building in Elk Grove Village.  Some trees fell onto vehicles in Chicago.  Peak wind gusts included 62 mph at DuPage Airport; 61 mph at Aurora Municipal Airport; 59 mph at Chicago Midway and Chicago Executive Airports and 58 mph at Waukegan Airport.

column37: High winds developed in the early morning hours of November 5th blowing down trees, tree limbs and a light pole in Chicago.  At least two cars were damaged by falling trees.
column38: A strong cold front moved across northern Illinois during the late morning and early afternoon of November 5th with convective showers which produced thunderstorm wind damage and one tornado. Strong south winds gusted from 40 up to around 50 mph. The highest measured wind gust was 51 mph at the Carbondale airport. Other notable wind gusts included 48 mph at the Harrisburg airport, 47 mph at the Marion airport, and 43 mph at the Cairo and Mount Vernon airports. In Herrin, a tree fell and crushed a fence in a residential area. In Marion, part of a large tree limb went through a home. The strong south winds occurred ahead of a cold front that trailed south from a low pressure center over the upper Mississippi Valley.

column37: A 60mph wind gust was measured at the Coles County Airport.
column38: A deepening area of low pressure tracking from northern Missouri to southern Wisconsin pulled a cold front through central Illinois during the morning of November 5th.  Strong southerly winds gusting over 50mph ahead of the front produced scattered wind damage.    In addition, a narrow line of showers with a few embedded thunderstorms immediately along the front was able to tap into higher momentum air aloft, resulting in a few wind gusts in excess of 60mph along the line.  The highest wind gusts were generally concentrated along and north of I-72, with Willard Airport in Champaign measuring a peak gust of 68mph.

column37: A 59mph wind gust was measured at the Edgar County Airport.

column37: Law Enforcement reported a tree down on route 6 in northeast of Coal Valley. The time of the event was estimated using radar.
column38: A strong storm system brought much needed rainfall to northwest Illinois the morning of November 4th through the 5th. This also brought two rounds of severe weather to northwest Illinois. On the morning of November 5th, a cold front moved across northwest Illinois and combined with a low level jet resulted in a rapidly strengthening line of storms that produced wind damage as it moved across northwest Illinois along and north of interstate 80 Heavy rain also fell with this storm system with 48 hour rainfall totals of 0.5 to 1.5 inches across northwest Illinois with the heaviest rains reported north of a Clinton Iowa to Freeport Illinois.

column38: A deepening area of low pressure tracking from northern Missouri to southern Wisconsin pulled a cold front through central Illinois during the morning of November 5th.  Strong southerly winds gusting over 50mph ahead of the front produced scattered wind damage.    In addition, a narrow line of showers with a few embedded thunderstorms immediately along the front was able to tap into higher momentum air aloft, resulting in a few wind gusts in excess of 60mph along the line.  The highest wind gusts were generally concentrated along and north of I-72, with Willard Airport in Champaign measuring a peak gust of 68mph.

column37: A 66mph wind gust was measured 2 miles south-southeast of Urbana.

column37: There were multiple reports of tree and power line damage in the Aurora area.  Some of the more significant reports included a 40 inch diameter Locust tree uprooted on Kennsington; a 36 inch diameter tree uprooted on West Downer; two 30 inch diameter trees snapped at the trunk, one on Havenshire Road and the other on Legacy; a 26 inch diameter tree uprooted on East Galena and a 20 inch diameter tree uprooted at Broadway and Washington.
column38: A strong cold front moved across northern Illinois during the late morning and early afternoon of November 5th with convective showers which produced thunderstorm wind damage and one tornado.  Wind damage from the convection was described as countywide across Ogle, Boone and McHenry Counties.  DuPage Airport measured a peak wind gust to 77 mph.  A handheld anemometer measured a wind gust to 80 mph near Roselle.||High winds caused tree damage both in the early morning of November 5th and then again in the afternoon of November 5th.  A large portion of a roof was blown off an apartment building in Elk Grove Village.  Some trees fell onto vehicles in Chicago.  Peak wind gusts included 62 mph at DuPage Airport; 61 mph at Aurora Municipal Airport; 59 mph at Chicago Midway and Chicago Executive Airports and 58 mph at Waukegan Airport.

column37: Several trees and power lines were blown down across McHenry County.

A very early season snowfall blanketed southern Illinois during the early morning hours. The highest accumulations ranged from two to three inches along and southeast of a line from Mount Carmel to Harrisburg to Cairo. Places from Mount Vernon to Carbondale received less than an inch. Most of the snow fell in just 1 to 3 hours.  Visibility was below one mile in the heaviest snow bands. Because temperatures had been in the 60's, 70's, and even lower 80's in the days preceding the snow, pavement temperatures were such that the snow melted on roads. However, snowfall rates were high enough to briefly cover bridges and overpasses, resulting in a few accidents. This unseasonably early snowfall was the third earliest snow event of an inch or more at Paducah, Kentucky (across the Ohio River from Metropolis, IL). The earliest was on the day before Halloween of 1993 (2 inches), and the second earliest was on November 11, 2019 (1.2 inches). The snow occurred in cold northerly flow behind a strong cold front and ahead of a deep 500 mb trough from the upper Missississippi Valley to the Ozark plateau.
