The snow occurred in cold northerly flow behind a strong cold front and ahead of a deep 500 mb trough from the upper Missississippi Valley to the Ozark plateau.

A very early season snowfall blanketed southern Illinois during the early morning hours. The highest accumulations ranged from two to three inches along and southeast of a line from Mount Carmel to Harrisburg to Cairo. Places from Mount Vernon to Carbondale received less than an inch. Most of the snow fell in just 1 to 3 hours.  Visibility was below one mile in the heaviest snow bands. Because temperatures had been in the 60's, 70's, and even lower 80's in the days preceding the snow, pavement temperatures were such that the snow melted on roads. However, snowfall rates were high enough to briefly cover bridges and overpasses, resulting in a few accidents. Drought conditions improved significantly across southern Illinois during the month. The drought was no longer categorized as severe by the end of the month. Most crops had been harvested, so agricultural impacts were limited. Wildfire danger decreased greatly by late in the month. Water levels on the Mississippi River increased, though they were below normal through the end of the month.

Widespread dense fog formed across far southern Illinois, mainly along and southwest of a line from Carbondale to Elizabethtown in Hardin County. The visibility was at or below one-quarter mile at times during the late night and early morning hours. The dense fog formed in the vicinity of a warm front that extended from the Ozarks of Missouri to just north of the Ohio River.

Widespread dense fog reduced visibility to one-quarter mile or less across parts of southern Illinois, mainly along and west of a Mount Vernon to Marion to Metropolis line. The late-night dense fog formed in the vicinity of a surface trough of low pressure extending from the Missouri bootheel northeast along the Ohio River.

column37: Snowfall reports ranged from 1.9 inches from a COOP observer 3 miles north northeast of Stockton to a CoCoRAHS observer 2 miles east of east Dubuque.  Winds quickly increased with gusts of 40 to 50 MPH which lead to widespread blowing and drifting snow.  Additionally, the winds also produced wind chills.
column38: A strong winter storm brought widespread snow to the region Thursday, with widespread amounts  between 1 to 4 inches. Strong winds also accompanied the snow, which caused significant blowing and drifting, especially in rural areas.  Many accidents were reported on Interstate 80, causing frequent backups.  Even stronger winds were observed on Friday across the area, and.  Wind gusts between 40-50 mph were common, creating ground blizzard conditions primarily along and north of Interstate 80. ||Additionally, temperatures dropped sharply behind the arctic cold front on Thursday and continued to fall throughout the day.  Single digit temperatures with wind chills between -20 and -40 degrees were common.

column37: The COOP observer in Mount Carroll reported 4.0 inches of snow. Other snowfall reports ranged from 2.1 inches from a trained spotter in Milledgeville to 4.7 inches from a trained spotter 6 miles south southeast of Elmoville.  Winds increased quickly behind a strong cold front with gusts of 40 to 50 MPH leading to reduced visibilities in blowing and drifting snow. Temperatures also dropped quickly with wind chills of -20 to -30. The coldest wind chills occurred on the 23rd.

column37: The official NWS observation at the Moline-Quad Cities Airport was 0.9 inches of snow. An additional snowfall report from a mesonet site 3 miles north northeast of Rock island was 1.5 inches. Snowfall reports ranged from 2.0 inches from the COOP observer in Freeport to 3.8 inches from a CoCoRAHS observer 3 miles north northeast of McConnell.  Winds increased quickly behind a strong cold front with gusts of 40 to 50 MPH leading to reduced visibilities in blowing and drifting snow. The peak measured gust by the ASOS at the Moline Quad Cities Airport was 49 MPH. Temperatures also dropped quickly with wind chills of -20 to -30. The lowest wind chill reported was -24The coldest wind chills occurred on the 23rd.

column37: Weather observers across Cass County reported 1 to 3 inches of snow.  Strong northwesterly winds gusting in excess of 40mph created near white-out conditions at times, especially in rural locations.  Numerous traffic accidents occurred as roads became snow-covered and hazardous.  In addition, temperatures plunging below zero created life-threatening conditions for anyone venturing outside.
column38: An Arctic cold front pushed through central Illinois on December 22nd, causing temperatures to plummet from early morning highs in the 30s to evening lows from zero to ten below zero.  As weak waves of low pressure tracked along the front, light snow developed across the area...with accumulations ranging from 1 to 3 inches.  Despite the overall light snowfall, strong winds gusting in excess of 40mph created considerable blowing and drifting snow which led to near zero visibility at times...particularly in open, rural locations.  The combination of falling snow, blowing snow, low visibility, and extremely cold temperatures caused major disruption to commerce and travel across central Illinois.  Numerous schools and businesses closed due to the inclement weather and several traffic accidents occurred as roads became snow-covered and slick.  In addition, scattered power outages were reported.

An arctic cold front moved across northern Illinois during the late morning and afternoon of December 22nd.  Temperatures fell from the lower to middle 30s into the single digits within hours.  Snow quickly spread across the region with roads becoming snow covered.  The snow tapered off to snow showers in the evening and snow showers continued through the afternoon of December 23rd.  Total snowfall amounts were generally in the 1 to 3 inch range with an area of 3 to 5 inches across far northwest Illinois.  Winds gusted as high as 55 mph through the morning of December 23rd and continued gusting to 40 mph through that evening producing widespread blowing snow and near whiteout conditions in many areas, especially in rural and open areas.

column37: Between 1 and 2 inches of snow fell. The snow combined with gusty northwest winds (35-45 mph gusts) created extremely hazardous travel with sporadic near-blizzard conditions during the heaviest snowfall. Road conditions deteriorated rapidly during this event. Several accidents occurred across the county due to slick snow packed roads.
column38: A strong arctic cold front moved through the region December 22nd.  The system brought a very rare combination of accumulating snowfall (generally 1-3) combined with very strong northwest winds (20-30 mph sustained, 35-45 mph gusts) which yielded sporadic near-blizzard conditions during the heaviest snowfall. Travel was extremely hazardous if not impossible during this time due to the falling (and blowing) snow. The bottom line is while snowfall amounts were not too substantial, the focus was on the high impacts to travel and the extremely dangerous cold/wind chills. Minimum wind chills Thursday night (12/22) into Friday morning (12/23) were in the -25 to - 40F range. For reference, these numbers were in the top 10 coldest observed at all three of our official climate stations (KSTL, KCOU, KUIN). Temperature wise, widespread below zero lows Friday morning (12/23) and were the coldest December temperatures seen in our area since December 23, 1989 (though about 10 degrees warmer). There were dozens of accidents across the county warning area during this event with a number of injuries ranging from minor to serious, but no deaths were reported.

Numerous schools and businesses closed due to the inclement weather and several traffic accidents occurred as roads became snow-covered and slick.  In addition, scattered power outages were reported.

column37: Between 1 and 2 inches of snow fell. The snow combined with gusty northwest winds (35-45 mph gusts) created extremely hazardous travel with sporadic near-blizzard conditions during the heaviest snowfall. Road conditions deteriorated rapidly during this event.
column38: A strong arctic cold front moved through the region December 22nd.  The system brought a very rare combination of accumulating snowfall (generally 1-3) combined with very strong northwest winds (20-30 mph sustained, 35-45 mph gusts) which yielded sporadic near-blizzard conditions during the heaviest snowfall. Travel was extremely hazardous if not impossible during this time due to the falling (and blowing) snow. The bottom line is while snowfall amounts were not too substantial, the focus was on the high impacts to travel and the extremely dangerous cold/wind chills. Minimum wind chills Thursday night (12/22) into Friday morning (12/23) were in the -25 to - 40F range. For reference, these numbers were in the top 10 coldest observed at all three of our official climate stations (KSTL, KCOU, KUIN). Temperature wise, widespread below zero lows Friday morning (12/23) and were the coldest December temperatures seen in our area since December 23, 1989 (though about 10 degrees warmer). There were dozens of accidents across the county warning area during this event with a number of injuries ranging from minor to serious, but no deaths were reported.

An arctic cold front moved across northern Illinois during the late morning and afternoon of December 22nd.  Temperatures fell from the lower to middle 30s into the single digits within hours.  Snow quickly spread across the region with roads becoming snow covered.  The snow tapered off to snow showers in the evening and snow showers continued through the afternoon of December 23rd.  Total snowfall amounts were generally in the 1 to 3 inch range with an area of 3 to 5 inches across far northwest Illinois.  Winds gusted as high as 55 mph through the morning of December 23rd and continued gusting to 40 mph through that evening producing widespread blowing snow and near whiteout conditions in many areas, especially in rural and open areas.

An arctic cold front moved across northern Illinois during the late morning and afternoon of December 22nd.  Temperatures fell from the lower to middle 30s into the single digits within hours.  Snow quickly spread across the region with roads becoming snow covered.  The snow tapered off to snow showers in the evening and snow showers continued through the afternoon of December 23rd.  Total snowfall amounts were generally in the 1 to 3 inch range with an area of 3 to 5 inches across far northwest Illinois.  Winds gusted as high as 55 mph through the morning of December 23rd and continued gusting to 40 mph through that evening producing widespread blowing snow and near whiteout conditions in many areas, especially in rural and open areas.

column37: Up to one inch of snow fell. The snow combined with gusty northwest winds (35-45 mph gusts) created extremely hazardous travel with sporadic near-blizzard conditions during the heaviest snowfall. Road conditions deteriorated rapidly during this event.
column38: A strong arctic cold front moved through the region December 22nd.  The system brought a very rare combination of accumulating snowfall (generally 1-3) combined with very strong northwest winds (20-30 mph sustained, 35-45 mph gusts) which yielded sporadic near-blizzard conditions during the heaviest snowfall. Travel was extremely hazardous if not impossible during this time due to the falling (and blowing) snow. The bottom line is while snowfall amounts were not too substantial, the focus was on the high impacts to travel and the extremely dangerous cold/wind chills. Minimum wind chills Thursday night (12/22) into Friday morning (12/23) were in the -25 to - 40F range. For reference, these numbers were in the top 10 coldest observed at all three of our official climate stations (KSTL, KCOU, KUIN). Temperature wise, widespread below zero lows Friday morning (12/23) and were the coldest December temperatures seen in our area since December 23, 1989 (though about 10 degrees warmer). There were dozens of accidents across the county warning area during this event with a number of injuries ranging from minor to serious, but no deaths were reported.

column37: Weather observers across Cumberland County reported around 1 inch of snow.  Several traffic accidents occurred as water froze on roadways.  In addition, temperatures plunging below zero created life-threatening conditions for anyone venturing outside.
column38: An Arctic cold front pushed through central Illinois on December 22nd, causing temperatures to plummet from early morning highs in the 30s to evening lows from zero to ten below zero.  As weak waves of low pressure tracked along the front, light snow developed across the area...with accumulations ranging from 1 to 3 inches.  Despite the overall light snowfall, strong winds gusting in excess of 40mph created considerable blowing and drifting snow which led to near zero visibility at times...particularly in open, rural locations.  The combination of falling snow, blowing snow, low visibility, and extremely cold temperatures caused major disruption to commerce and travel across central Illinois.  Numerous schools and businesses closed due to the inclement weather and several traffic accidents occurred as roads became snow-covered and slick.  In addition, scattered power outages were reported.

A powerful cold front swept through the region, with wind chills dropping to 20 to 30 below zero. These were the coldest wind chills observed in over 25 years across the region. Paducah, KY dropped down to a -21 wind chill, which was the coldest since February 3, 1996. The most extreme wind chills were from the evening of the 22nd to the morning of the 23rd, but wind chills as late as the morning of December 24th were often below minus 10. Actual air temperatures only reached the single digits above zero on the 23rd, which followed morning lows around 5 below. Peak wind gusts of 35 to 50 mph were observed during this event as well. The peak gust at Carbondale was 44 mph on the evening of the 22nd. The extreme cold was indirectly responsible for a number of structure fires caused by supplemental heating sources, such as space heaters. One hypothermia fatality was reported in Pulaski County. A 67-year-old male residing in a condemned structure with no utilities was found deceased. There were numerous reports of frozen water pipes that burst and flooded homes and other buildings. In Harrisburg, a nursing home roof collapsed due to busted water pipes. An underground water main burst in Carterville, leading officials to issue a boil water advisory for the city. An antique shop burned in Pinckneyville, and firefighters were hampered by low water pressure. On top of the extreme cold, one to three inches of snow fell. The highest amounts were in the Ohio River counties from Cairo to Metropolis and Golconda, where around 3 inches fell. Snowfall amounts elsewhere were from 1 to 2 inches. This snow and the accompanying flash freeze heavily impacted travel across the region. Despite relatively light traffic, there were numerous traffic mishaps.

An arctic cold front moved across northern Illinois during the late morning and afternoon of December 22nd.  Temperatures were in the lower to middle 30s ahead of the front and fell into the single digits within hours after the cold front passed.  Low temperatures by the morning of December 23rd ranged from 5 below to 12 below zero.  High temperatures on December 23rd remained in the low single digits below zero.  Winds gusted as high as 55 mph through the morning of December 23rd and continued gusting to 40 mph through the evening of December 23rd.  The combination of strong winds and sub zero temperatures produced wind chills between 30 below and 42 below zero.  While temperatures slowly warmed to near zero by the morning of December 24th, winds continued gusting to 35 mph.  Wind chills finally warmed above 20 below zero by the late morning of December 24th.

A 67-year-old male residing in a condemned structure with no utilities was found deceased. There were numerous reports of frozen water pipes that burst and flooded homes and other buildings. In Harrisburg, a nursing home roof collapsed due to busted water pipes. An underground water main burst in Carterville, leading officials to issue a boil water advisory for the city. An antique shop burned in Pinckneyville, and firefighters were hampered by low water pressure. On top of the extreme cold, one to three inches of snow fell. The highest amounts were in the Ohio River counties from Cairo to Metropolis and Golconda, where around 3 inches fell. Snowfall amounts elsewhere were from 1 to 2 inches. This snow and the accompanying flash freeze heavily impacted travel across the region. Despite relatively light traffic, there were numerous traffic mishaps.

A powerful cold front swept through the region, with wind chills dropping to 20 to 30 below zero. These were the coldest wind chills observed in over 25 years across the region. Paducah, KY dropped down to a -21 wind chill, which was the coldest since February 3, 1996. The most extreme wind chills were from the evening of the 22nd to the morning of the 23rd, but wind chills as late as the morning of December 24th were often below minus 10. Actual air temperatures only reached the single digits above zero on the 23rd, which followed morning lows around 5 below. Peak wind gusts of 35 to 50 mph were observed during this event as well. The peak gust at Carbondale was 44 mph on the evening of the 22nd. The most extreme wind chills were from the evening of the 22nd to the morning of the 23rd, but wind chills as late as the morning of December 24th were often below minus 10. Actual air temperatures only reached the single digits above zero on the 23rd, which followed morning lows around 5 below. Peak wind gusts of 35 to 50 mph were observed during this event as well. The peak gust at Carbondale was 44 mph on the evening of the 22nd. The extreme cold was indirectly responsible for a number of structure fires caused by supplemental heating sources, such as space heaters. One hypothermia fatality was reported in Pulaski County. A 67-year-old male residing in a condemned structure with no utilities was found deceased. There were numerous reports of frozen water pipes that burst and flooded homes and other buildings. In Harrisburg, a nursing home roof collapsed due to busted water pipes. An underground water main burst in Carterville, leading officials to issue a boil water advisory for the city. An antique shop burned in Pinckneyville, and firefighters were hampered by low water pressure. On top of the extreme cold, one to three inches of snow fell. The highest amounts were in the Ohio River counties from Cairo to Metropolis and Golconda, where around 3 inches fell. Snowfall amounts elsewhere were from 1 to 2 inches. This snow and the accompanying flash freeze heavily impacted travel across the region. Despite relatively light traffic, there were numerous traffic mishaps.

An arctic cold front moved across northern Illinois during the late morning and afternoon of December 22nd.  Temperatures were in the lower to middle 30s ahead of the front and fell into the single digits within hours after the cold front passed.  Low temperatures by the morning of December 23rd ranged from 5 below to 12 below zero.  High temperatures on December 23rd remained in the low single digits below zero.  Winds gusted as high as 55 mph through the morning of December 23rd and continued gusting to 40 mph through the evening of December 23rd.  The combination of strong winds and sub zero temperatures produced wind chills between 30 below and 42 below zero.  While temperatures slowly warmed to near zero by the morning of December 24th, winds continued gusting to 35 mph.  Wind chills finally warmed above 20 below zero by the late morning of December 24th.

column37: Temperatures between zero and ten degrees below zero and wind speeds of 25 to 35 mph resulted in a prolonged period of wind chills colder than 25 degrees below zero. The coldest wind chill observed at the Marshall County Airport (KC75) was 31 degrees below zero.
column38: A strong low pressure system and its associated cold front moved through the Midwest on December 22nd, 2022. In its wake, frigid temperatures and strong winds resulted in a prolonged period of dangerous wind chills, as cold as 35 degrees below zero, across central Illinois on December 23rd and into the morning of December 24th.

In its wake, frigid temperatures and strong winds resulted in a prolonged period of dangerous wind chills, as cold as 35 degrees below zero, across central Illinois on December 23rd and into the morning of December 24th.

column37: Trained spotter reports ranged from 1 inch in Fulton to 2 inches 3 miles south southwest of Malvern. After the snow fell, winds increased with gusts of 40 to 50 MPH for several hours on the 22nd.  This lead to whiteout conditions especially in rural and open areas. The strong winds also caused dangerously cold wind chills with -27 reported at the Sterling-Rock Falls Airport.
column38: A strong winter storm brought widespread snow to the region Thursday, with widespread amounts  between 1 to 4 inches. Strong winds also accompanied the snow, which caused significant blowing and drifting, especially in rural areas.  Many accidents were reported on Interstate 80, causing frequent backups.  Even stronger winds were observed on Friday across the area, and.  Wind gusts between 40-50 mph were common, creating ground blizzard conditions primarily along and north of Interstate 80. ||Additionally, temperatures dropped sharply behind the arctic cold front on Thursday and continued to fall throughout the day.  Single digit temperatures with wind chills between -20 and -40 degrees were common.
Wind chills dropped to 20 below zero in some locations across northern Illinois during the early morning of December 25th.
Wind chills dropped to 20 below zero in some locations across northern Illinois during the early morning of December 25th.

A surface low pressure center and its parent 500 mb shortwave moved south-southeast from the northern Plains across the middle Mississippi Valley. An area of snow in advance of these features produced an inch or two of accumulation during the late night and early morning hours. The snow readily accumulated on road surfaces due to the antecedent frigid temperatures the previous few days. Driving conditions were treacherous during the morning commute, but relatively light traffic on the observed Christmas holiday kept traffic mishaps less numerous than they otherwise might have been.
